enhanced_description: Aggie STEM Camps, a collaboration between the College of Education and Human Development and the College of Engineering, offer project-based learning experiences for advanced students entering grades 3 through 12, including specialized options like the Gaddis Girls Camp. Elementary students can attend day camps that include snacks and a t-shirt, though they must provide their own lunch, while middle and high school students can participate in overnight programs featuring private rooms, shared common areas, and full meal service. Led by STEM professionals and university faculty, the curriculum explores engineering design, mathematical modeling, and advanced technological tools through a new theme and project-based classes each session. Registration is conducted on a first-come basis with a required deposit—$75 for day camps and a minimum of $500 for overnight sessions that may increase closer to the start of camp—and while fees are nonrefundable, they may be transferred to other sponsored camp weeks for a $25 fee after an initial grace period. Tuition is set at $425 for day camps, $1499 for middle school overnight camps, and $1699 for high school overnight camps, with scholarship applications and roommate requests available during the registration process.

title: PME University of Chicago
subtitle: Summer Lab and Research Experiences
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in hands-on research experiences in various scientific fields. Participants work closely with faculty and graduate students to explore scientific questions and develop skills in research methodology and critical thinking.

title: College of Design Pre-College
subtitle: Georgia Tech
raw_text: The Pre-College program consists of two-week in-person workshops in architecture, building construction, industrial design, or music technology. Hosted by the College of Design at the Georgia Institute of Technology, this program provides the opportunity to engage with our world-class faculty from Georgia Tech's community and current students and give high-school (rising juniors and rising seniors) students insight into what it is like to study at one of the Schools in the College of Design.

title: Yale Global Scholars
subtitle: Yale
raw_text: Yale Young Global Scholars (YYGS) is an academic enrichment program for outstanding high school students from around the world. Each summer, students from over 150 countries (including all 50 U.S. states) participate in one interdisciplinary, two-week session at Yale’s historic campus. Immerse yourself in a global learning community at Yale University.

title: Science Program
subtitle: SSP
raw_text: The Summer Science Program is not a “camp.” It is a unique immersion experience with a strong culture that has evolved over more than half a century. It is talented young people discovering their limits, then overcoming them through collaboration. It is the shock of not being the smartest person in the room, followed by the joy of realizing that’s not a problem, it’s an opportunity.

title: Summer Scholars
subtitle: UND
raw_text: Summer Scholars participants spend two intensive weeks on Notre Dame's campus taking a challenging college-level course taught by Notre Dame faculty. We keep the classes small and personal attention from Notre Dame faculty high. The coursework is a true preview of college academics—it is both rigorous and rewarding, and students could earn one transferable college credit upon the completion of a program track. Students collaborate on coursework outside designated class times as they would in any college setting. There is also ample time to enjoy the social facets of college life, especially those unique to Notre Dame.

title: Future Leaders Program
subtitle: UCSD
raw_text: This unique summer program is designed for high school students to develop problem-solving and diplomacy skills in global affairs, especially as they pertain to the roles of China, the U.S., Pacific and Indo-Pacific region countries including Mexico and India. In this program, you will participate in role-playing teams using a digital simulation platform. Through guided readings, lectures, discussion and negotiations, you will produce an action plan that emphasizes common-ground solutions in four areas: climate crisis, energy innovation (e.g. renewable energy, electric vehicles, etc.), artificial intelligence and global pandemics.

title: Med-Start Health Program
subtitle: UArizona
raw_text: The Med-Start Health Careers Program is a six-week summer academic enrichment program focused on improving access to information and resources for 11th Grade High School  students interested in the health professions. High School students reside at the University of Arizona Residence Hall and participate in the program during the summer (Beginning of June-Mid July) after completing their  junior year.

title: High School Research Internship
subtitle: BTI
raw_text: BTI 2024 High School Research Experience will be open to current high school students over the age of 16 by the start of the program and are available to participate in-person full-time from June 25th to August 9th (Monday through Friday). Selected students will receive an educational stipend of $4,200 for the program. Housing and meal stipends are not included in the high school research program.

title: Nurse Camp
subtitle: UNLV
raw_text: UNLV Nurse Camp welcomes all high school students (rising freshmen – graduating seniors) interested in health sciences and nursing to attend Nurse Camp.  Campers participate in academic, clinical, and community activities to explore the nursing profession.  UNLV Nurse Camp will run two sessions this summer, each session will accept 30 campers.

title: Pathways Research Internship
subtitle: Yale
raw_text: Yale Pathways Research Internships (YPRI) connects qualified public high school students from the New Haven area with scientific research labs at Yale for a seven-week summer internship. These research experiences excite students about scientific investigation, enable them to explore new scientific fields, and increase their college preparedness. In doing so, we aim to foster long-term relationships between Yale laboratories and accomplished high school students who are enthusiastic about pursuing research.

title: Summer Internship Program
subtitle: Cancer Research Center of Hawai’i
raw_text: The UH Cancer Center High School Cancer Research Program is a one-week structured course to introduce students to the world of cancer research and related careers. The program emphasizes hands-on activities in population science research to cultivate an interest in education and research careers focused on cancer prevention and health disparities in Hawaiʻi.

title: TRIO Upward Bound Math & Science
subtitle: UNLV
raw_text: Upward Bound Math & Science is a college preparatory program for first-generation and income-qualified students from select target high schools. The program is federally funded through the U.S. Department of Education and is FREE to all participants. This is a supportive program that identifies, motivates, and prepares participants to complete high school, enroll in, and graduate from institutions of post-secondary education.

title: Reflections Competition
subtitle: PTA
raw_text: The PTA Reflections program encourages students to explore their creativity through various artistic categories, including visual arts, dance, music, and literature. Participants submit original works based on a chosen theme. The program aims to promote artistic expression and provide opportunities for students to showcase their talents. Winners at local, state, and national levels receive recognition and awards. The program supports the development of artistic skills and creativity among students.

title: Bentley University
subtitle: Analytics Academy
raw_text: The Analytics Academy at Bentley University offers high school students the opportunity to explore data analytics through hands-on learning experiences. Participants will engage in real-world projects and gain insights into the field of analytics while developing essential skills for future academic and career success.

title: YTI Online
subtitle: Emory
raw_text: YTI Online meets weekly for one hour. Often we focus our conversations around a book we read together that we provide to you. Group members decide how we proceed and what we read. ​This is a time and space where you can get support from adults who relate to you as equals and where you can ask any and all questions you have about God, the Bible, the world, any questions you are carrying with you.

title: Summer Journalism
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: NYU's Summer Journalism program offers intensive courses for precollege, undergraduate, and visiting students, with options for both two- and four-credit classes. The program includes sessions from May 20 to July 2 and July 3 to August 15, 2024. It covers various topics, such as narrative podcasting, arts reporting, and neighborhood news. Participants gain hands-on experience and learn from distinguished faculty. The program is open to international students and provides limited scholarships.

title: USAMO
subtitle: MAA
raw_text: The United States of America Mathematical Olympiad (USAMO) is a prestigious math competition for high school students, focusing on advanced problem-solving skills. It is one of the key stages in the selection process for the U.S. Math Team competing in international events. The competition involves a rigorous exam with challenging mathematical problems. USAMO aims to identify and nurture top mathematical talent in the United States. Students who excel in USAMO may advance to the International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO).

title: USA Computing Olympiad
subtitle: USACO
raw_text: The USA Computing Olympiad (USACO) is a prestigious competition for high school students focusing on computer programming and algorithmic problem-solving. Participants compete in online contests that test their coding skills and knowledge of algorithms. The competition aims to identify and nurture top programming talent and prepare students for future challenges in computer science. USACO provides opportunities for students to showcase their skills and advance to international competitions. Success in USACO can lead to further academic and career opportunities in computing.

title: Summer Seminar
subtitle: USNA
raw_text: Summer Seminar kick-starts your Naval Academy application by giving you a taste of life at the Academy. For one week in June, you will experience first-class academic, athletic and professional training while building lifelong friendships with campers from all over the world.

title: National Arts Competition
subtitle: Young Arts
raw_text: YoungArts provides opportunities for high school students to showcase their talents in visual, literary, and performing arts. Participants apply to be considered for awards, scholarships, and mentorship programs. The competition aims to identify and support emerging young artists in various disciplines. Winners receive recognition, opportunities for professional development, and connections with industry professionals. YoungArts fosters artistic growth and career development for talented students.

title: R Programming & Machine Learning Camp
subtitle: UMich
raw_text: This camp provides statistical methods in the context of disease research. It is for current (2023-24) high school and exceptional 8th grade students who want to learn computer programming for future biomedical applications. R is a statistical tool and programming language with excellent graphic options, useful in various application areas such as medicine, public policy, and economics. After R is introduced, the students will assess current biomedical problems and identify useful tools for research. The R Programming Camp is not just a programming camp; it provides essential tools and datasets with which students can develop their own research projects. Students will learn TCGA big data analysis using microRNA sequencing data of cancer patients. We will use an R machine learning package during the camp. Finally, students will learn to generate scientific graphics useful for professional presentations such as in publications and at science fairs.

title: Collegiate Seminar Program
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: The NYU Collegiate Seminar Program offers high school juniors the opportunity to experience college-level classes at a top-tier research university. Selected students will participate in one or more two-hour seminar-style classes taught by leading NYU faculty in a variety of academic subjects. This fall, you can experience the dynamic, intellectually rigorous environment of an NYU classroom as a high school student. Small, seminar-style classes allow students to engage in discussion with faculty and classmates on some of today's most pressing topics. Explore how photography can be used to advocate for social change; discover how climate change is impacting urban infrastructure design; or examine religious liberty under U.S. law. View the Fall 2024 Collegiate Seminar schedule below.

title: GSTEM Online Data Science
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: Expand your love for STEM with our data science class designed for all levels. You will gain the ability to gather, process, analyze, and visualize data.  A great opportunity to study beyond your high school curriculum.

title: Terp Young Scholars
subtitle: UMD
raw_text: This summer, learn to navigate the college experience with the University of Maryland’s Terp Young Scholars. During three remarkable weeks, academically talented students pursue an academic interest, engage with passionate faculty, and get a jump on college by earning three university credits.  Terp Young Scholars offers two learning options—in-person or online. Both options provide innovative and engaging learning. Participants choose whether to commute from home or participate 100% online. Students who select the commuter in-person learning option discover UMD’s outstanding facilities and amenities while living at home and commuting daily to the UMD campus. Students who select the 100% online learning option engage in interactive virtual activities that provide insights into the UMD experience.

title: Vanderbilt University
subtitle: Vanderbilt Summer Research Internship Program in Biomedical Informatics
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in biomedical informatics research at Vanderbilt University. Participants will work closely with faculty mentors gain hands-on experience and develop skills in data analysis and research methodologies in a collaborative environment.

title: Engineering Program
subtitle: Stony Brook
raw_text: Students will investigate concepts in electricity and magnetism by building electromagnets, electromagnetic motors, and generating electricity.  They will connect these concepts to larger applications in electrical engineering. The participants will begin to develop their skills in electronics by building some basic circuits and will advance to more complex electronics projects using breadboards and microprocessors. They will each receive a credit-card sized computer called a Raspberry Pi and will learn how to develop code with it. The course will culminate with a project interfacing the Raspberry Pi with electronics components. The students will be able to take home these projects.

title: Oakland University
subtitle: Emerging Scholars Program
raw_text: The Emerging Scholars Program is designed for high school students to explore college life and prepare for academic success. Participants will engage in coursework and activities that foster critical thinking and collaboration while gaining insights into college-level expectations and resources available to them.

title: ChemiCo
subtitle: Stemco
raw_text: STEM Competition Chemico challenges high school students to develop solutions and projects related to chemistry and chemical engineering. Participants work on innovative projects that address real-world chemical challenges. The competition aims to inspire students to pursue careers in chemistry and chemical engineering. It provides opportunities for students to showcase their skills and gain recognition for their work. Winners receive awards and support for further development of their projects.

title: Scripps College of Communication
subtitle: Ohio University
raw_text: The High School Media Workshop at Ohio University offers students the chance to explore various aspects of media production including video photography and digital storytelling. Participants will engage in hands-on learning experiences and collaborate with peers while developing their creative skills in a supportive environment.

title: The Cutting-Edge of Biological Discovery
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: Cells are fantastically complicated, dynamic packages of life that we still poorly understand. What recent discoveries are revolutionizing our understanding of cells? What’s the connection between cell organization and human diseases? How do scientists use the tools of microscopy to further advance their knowledge? Get answers to these questions, dive into the world of cells, learn their language, and discover how new technologies are allowing us to not just better see, but also feel cells. Whether you’re looking to receive college credit or just immerse yourself in the world of biology before college, we have an option for you.

title: Girls in Math
subtitle: MMaths
raw_text: The Mathematical Association of America's (MAA) American Mathematics Competitions (AMC) is a series of mathematics contests for high school students. The AMC 10 and AMC 12 focus on problem-solving and mathematical reasoning. Participants compete for awards based on their scores and progress to higher-level competitions. The AMC aims to promote mathematical excellence and critical thinking. Winners receive recognition and opportunities for further mathematical development.

title: Filmmakers Workshop
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: The emphasis of the Online High School Filmmakers Workshops is storytelling through visual language. Through online courses and skill-building projects, high school students develop their writing, directing, shooting, and editing skills as they produce a variety of short films. Students deliver a crew-based documentary, a crew-based music video, three technical assignments, and a final narrative film. This online workshop is delivered through an asynchronous model, with pre-recorded video lectures and modules. Students watch the videos at their own pace and complete daily and/or weekly assignments. Students will schedule real-time video meetings with their instructor and film crew.

title: University of Cincinnati
subtitle: Medical Sciences Summer Institute
raw_text: The Medical Sciences Summer Institute is designed for high school juniors interested in pursuing a career in medicine. Participants will engage in hands-on learning experiences and gain insights into medical education and practice. The program also includes workshops and networking opportunities with professionals in the field.

title: Summer Research Experience
subtitle: PARI
raw_text: Our programs for middle school and high school aged campers provide hands-on explorations into astronomy and space science and the tools to make discoveries of their own. Explore the universe with state of the art STEM technology, like NASA built radio telescopes, research grade optical telescopes, and one of the world’s largest archives of astronomical data. Conduct independent and group research under the mentorship of astronomers and scientists. Campers will earn an official research certificate and will have their work published in PARI’s summer research proceedings, with an opportunity to submit their work to a regional conference. Tour cutting edge astronomy research labs at Clemson University Have a blast with fellow campers through STEM challenges, field trips, games, and more! (river tubing, hiking, PARI Ball, campfires, swimming at waterfalls, and rocketry competitions, to name a few)

title: ASSIP Program
subtitle: George Mason
raw_text: The nationally known Aspiring Scientists Summer Internship Program (ASSIP) provides transformative research opportunities for high school and undergraduate students. Selected participants work one-on-one with faculty researchers at George Mason University and collaborating institutions using state-of-the-art technology across many disciplines.

title: Academic Summer Camps
subtitle: Northwestern
raw_text:

2026 Academic Summer Camp Tuition

Tuition rates vary by session and course type ($1,005 - $6,105)
Prepare for the Future while Enjoying the Summer

CTD's Academic Day and Residential Camps for students grades 6-12 (entering grade in fall 2026) offer high-achieving, motivated middle and high school students the opportunity to receive high school, college-level and pre-professional instruction from master teachers and industry leaders. Fast-paced, intensive courses engage students in critical and creative problem solving as they grapple with advanced concepts in subjects from math and science to writing and technology to leadership and service-learning, producing products such as writing portfolios, original iOS apps, or community action plans.

Why Choose CTD's Academic Camps?

Accelerated coursework and immersive learning experiences help students build confidence in their talents and potential. Master instructors, community partners, and industry experts support students as they explore possible career paths. Community with like-minded peers from around the country and across the globe provide the inspiration and support needed to stretch and grow. CTD participants develop their individual talents as they learn how to make positive change in their communities. In addition, residential camps immerse students in the beautiful lakeside campus of Northwestern University. Residential camp programming emphasizes the formation of life-long friendships and the independence needed to succeed at university and beyond. 

Benefits include:

Small class sizes and individual attention
Opportunities to network with a a global community of peers
Preparation for high school, college, and career
High-quality instruction using a talent development framework and best practices in gifted education
In addition to Academic Day and Residential Camp options, CTD offers a diverse range of online program options; view a full list here.

enhanced_description: The Center for Talent Development (CTD) offers academic camps for high-achieving students in grades 6 through 12, featuring both one-week and three-week sessions with day and residential attendance options. Participants engage in fast-paced, intensive coursework led by master teachers and industry experts, covering diverse subjects such as math, science, technology, writing, and leadership. These programs provide opportunities for enrichment, high school credit, and AP-level study, allowing students to produce tangible outcomes like original iOS apps or community action plans while exploring potential career pathways. Tuition rates for these immersive experiences range from $1,005 to $6,105 depending on the specific session and course type. Beyond core academics, specialized tracks like the Summer Leadership Intensive and the Civic Leadership Institute focus on social issues and leadership development within a global community of peers.

title: Marching Band Camp
subtitle: UTA
raw_text: Grades (9-12) - The UTA drum major, leadership and colorguard camp is designed to strengthen the abilities of beginner, intermediate, and advanced students, while providing a variety of experiences in fundamentals, leadership, and performance. Colorguard students in middle school will also be accepted.

title: Georgia State
subtitle: SciSynth
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in innovative research projects that combine scientific inquiry with creative synthesis. Participants will work closely with faculty mentors and gain hands-on experience in various scientific disciplines.

title: Human Resources Intern
subtitle: IALR
raw_text: The Institute for Advanced Learning and Research (IALR) offers an annual summer internship program to provide meaningful on-the-job training. The internship program provides real-world leadership development experiences in diverse career fields such as research and data analysis, public relations, human resources, AgTech research, coding and robotics, information technology and more. Candidates for IALR internships must be: a high school graduate with plans to attend college in fall of 2024; an undergraduate or graduate level college student; OR a recent college graduate, within the last 12 months.

title: Project Ignite
subtitle: CMU
raw_text: Pursue a project outside the scope of typical schoolwork with mentorship from college students. Explore an existing interest you haven't yet had the opportunity to delve into, or broaden your horizons by gaining exposure to new fields. Develop critical thinking and problem-solving abilities through hands-on project experience. Increase your awareness of future paths, whether college or professional, and improve your time-management and budgeting skills. Learn to work effectively as a team.

title: Columbia Writing Academy: Summer
subtitle: Columbia
raw_text: As many colleges place less emphasis on standardized test scores, the admissions essay has taken a larger role in the application process. The Columbia Writing Academy is a two-week online course created and designed by Dr. Nancy Sommers to help students develop their own personal voice and style, and use those skills to craft a unique and impressive college admissions essay. Students will explore each stage in the essay-writing process—brainstorming, drafting, revising—and will receive in-depth feedback from the teaching team throughout the process. Due to the importance of small-group workshops and 1:1 tutorials, this course is intended for students highly motivated to perfect their personal statement.

title: Healthcare Exploration
subtitle: BHE
raw_text: The Buffalo Healthcare Exploration (BHE) program at Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center through the ATLAS Program offers an exceptional opportunity for high school students to delve into the exciting world of healthcare. Through hands-on experiences and mentorship, BHE equips young minds with valuable insights into various medical disciplines, fostering their passion and interest in the healthcare field.

title: Illini Summer Academies
subtitle: UIUC
raw_text: Illini Summer Academies is a life-changing personal development experience on the University of Illinois campus. Participants from around Illinois attend academy sessions led by university professors and enjoy a variety of educational sessions that provide a taste of what is possible after high school.

title: Business Opportunities Summer Session
subtitle: PSU
raw_text: BOSS is a two-week, residential program, for residents of the U.S. and Puerto Rico only, held on Penn State's University Park campus for high school juniors interested in pursuing a business education in college. It’s an opportunity for these students to take college prep and business fundamentals courses taught by Penn State faculty.  This is a sample schedule of what the two weeks would entail.

title: Entrepreneurship Challenge
subtitle: Diamond Challenge
raw_text: The Diamond Challenge invites high school students to develop and pitch entrepreneurial and social innovation projects. Participants work on creating business plans and solutions that address real-world issues. The competition provides mentorship, resources, and networking opportunities to support students in developing their ideas. The Diamond Challenge aims to inspire young entrepreneurs and innovators by offering a platform for showcasing their projects. Winners receive recognition and support for further development of their ventures.

title: Forensics Investigators
subtitle: Rice
raw_text: The Forensics Investigators Program offers an immersive and captivating experience tailored for high school students in grades 7-10 who have an interest in the intriguing realm of crime scene investigation and scientific exploration. Designed to blend scientific inquiry with real-world detective work, this program presents a distinctive chance for curious young minds to explore the fascinating field of forensic science.

title: Extended Studies
subtitle: UCSD
raw_text: The UC San Diego Summer Session program offers a diverse selection of courses for undergraduate and graduate students during the summer term. Students can enroll in classes to advance their academic progress, explore new subjects, or gain additional credits. The program includes options for on-campus housing, and students can access various academic resources and support services. Financial aid and scholarships may be available to help cover the costs. Overall, the Summer Session provides an opportunity to enhance learning and make the most of the academic year.

title: Athena Summer Innovation Institute
subtitle: Barnard
raw_text: The Athena Summer Innovation Institute is an intensive, 3-week boot camp that provides students with the practical skills and knowledge they need to develop ideas that will make a difference in the world. Students will work in teams to create a new venture — start-up businesses, non-profit organizations, or advocacy campaigns — that have the power to disrupt traditional ways of doing things and create lasting change.

title: Cooper Union
subtitle: Cooper Next Scholars
raw_text: The Cooper Next Scholars program is designed for high school students interested in engineering. Participants engage in hands-on projects and workshops led by experienced instructors. This immersive experience fosters creativity and innovation while providing insights into engineering principles and practices.

title: Health Professions Program
subtitle: Northwestern
raw_text: The Health Professions Recruitment & Exposure Program (HPREP) is an annual five-week educational program for high school students of diverse backgrounds from the Chicagoland area. The program is hosted by the Student National Medical Association (SNMA), Latino Medical Student Association (LMSA) and Feinberg Office of Diversity & Inclusion. HPREP gives students firsthand exposure to the medical school curriculum, career options in healthcare, tools for academic success and opportunities to interact with current medical students, graduate students, physician assistant (PA) students, physical therapy (PT) students, physicians, nurses and other healthcare professionals.

title: FIU
subtitle: Summer Research Internship
raw_text: This internship provides undergraduate students with hands-on research experience in various STEM fields. Participants will work closely with faculty mentors on innovative projects. The program aims to enhance research skills and foster a deeper understanding of scientific inquiry while promoting collaboration and networking among peers.

title: Summer Pre-College at the UMass Mount Ida Campus
subtitle: UMass
raw_text: Experience the academic quality of the UMass Amherst Pre-College program in the greater Boston area. Our pre-college programs at the Mount Ida Campus invite high school students to experience college-level classes and campus life, including our award-winning UMass dining, all from the convenient location of Newton, MA.

title: LUC
subtitle: Loyola University Chicago Social Justice Internship
raw_text: This internship provides students with the opportunity to engage in social justice initiatives through hands-on experience. Interns will work with community organizations focusing on advocacy and social change. Participants will gain valuable skills and knowledge while contributing to meaningful projects that impact the community.

title: Yale
subtitle: Yale University Summer Internship Program
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to work in a research lab at Yale University. Interns will gain hands-on experience in scientific research while collaborating with faculty and graduate students. The program aims to inspire students to pursue careers in science and research.

title: Summer Study
subtitle: Babson
raw_text: Babson Summer Study is a 3+ week experiential online program for rising high school juniors and seniors to develop an entrepreneurial mindset and become innovators and changemakers. By strengthening your understanding of the United Nations Global Goals, you will develop the competencies and confidence to address real-world problems, seize opportunities, have an impact, and create change that leads to your desired future. While you work with peers from around the globe, you will develop power skills that allow you to enroll others in your vision, confidently master difficult topics, and embrace other points of view all while earning 4 college credits from Babson, the top-ranked college for entrepreneurship.

title: Ann Arbor Entrepreneurship
subtitle: LaunchX

Our Curriculum
more information
Coursework that works

Our curriculum was designed by academic experts and practitioners specifically for high caliber students. The rigorous course material focuses on practical application that goes beyond theory.
enhanced_description: LaunchX provides high school students with hands-on experience in launching real startups through a rigorous curriculum focused on practical application and business theory. Participants are paired with a global community of peers using a specialized teaming formula designed to complement individual skill sets throughout the stages of identification, ideation, iteration, and implementation. The program offers various tracks including intensive entrepreneurship, online bootcamps for startup basics, innovation projects, and startup internships, all of which provide access to vetted industry mentors and the opportunity to achieve customer sales before a final Demo Day. Financial aid is available across these offerings, with costs ranging from $1,995 to $11,495 depending on the selected program format and commitment level. Interested students can apply through early or priority deadlines to secure their spots and potentially access additional aid or reduced application fees.

title: STRIDE Bioengineering
subtitle: UCR
raw_text: A new STEM program at UC Riverside for high school students will emphasize diversity, inclusion, equity and improving access to healthcare in the region. The Summer Training and Research Inspiration for Diverse Pipeline Engagement toward Advancing Stem Cell Treatment, or STRIDE, will be a 5-week summer research training program for 60 diverse high school students from throughout Riverside and San Bernardino counties, which comprise the Inland Empire.

title: Ellen Brenner Internship
subtitle: CSHL
raw_text: The Ellen Brenner Memorial Internship is one of the four types of awards offered by the CSHL Center for Humanities & History of Modern Biology. It was established in 2020 in memory of Ellen Brenner, who was a CSHL librarian and integral member of the lab community for nearly a decade. In her role supervising library volunteers, Ellen worked with many high school students, cultivating their interests in science and libraries. Interns will work with library collections, the CSHL institutional repository, and research publications of CSHL scientists. Through their work, they will learn how to use PubMed and other biomedical databases as well as specialized bibliographical resources. They can also develop projects related to specific archival collections or topics in the history of science, which will allow them to learn about different scientific fields. All projects will provide interns with experience working in a research library and scientific archives environment under the supervision of experienced professionals.

title: High School Summer Internship Program
subtitle: USC
raw_text: The USC Dornsife Center for the Political Future (CPF), in partnership with the USC Wrigley Institute for Environment and Sustainability, offers select high school students a prestigious summer internship program that is held entirely online. This competitive program gives high school students (no graduating seniors; sorry), who have a minimum 3.5 GPA, the opportunity to have a collegiate internship experience.

title: Forensics Exploration
subtitle: Stony Brook
raw_text: The Institute for STEM Education (I-STEM) is a major interdisciplinary STEM education center on the campus and has established a wide range of academic year and summer activities for faculty, graduate students, undergraduates and K-12 students and teachers. I-STEM’s mission is to provide comprehensive, high-quality STEM education that advances knowledge in the field. We work collaboratively across all levels of the educational spectrum to recognize, attract, nurture and develop talent. We expect that our faculty and the graduates of our programs will be leaders in the STEM education field through their production of new knowledge; the publication of their research in the leading journals; their presentations at state, national and international conferences and their influence upon key STEM policy initiatives. We believe that a sustained commitment to excellence in STEM education is imperative for the university and the nation.

title: Cyber Camp
subtitle: Oregon State
raw_text: Cybersecurity is an increasingly important field as technology continues to play a major role in our lives. From protecting personal and sensitive information to securing critical infrastructure, cybersecurity is a crucial aspect of modern society. This makes it an excellent career choice for those who are interested in problem-solving, technology and security. In this exciting camp, you’ll be introduced to some of the skills and techniques needed to solve a cyber crime. Join us and you’ll trace the path of cyber attackers through a network, dig up clues by performing digital forensics, and hopefully nab the hacker before they get away.  Taught by cybersecurity professionals, with guest speakers with various areas of expertise, this cyber camp will be a great introduction to the field of cybersecurity and an opportunity to meet new friends and have fun while developing skills that will be valuable in the future. Our goal is to provide a supportive and inclusive learning environment where participants can explore their interest in cybersecurity. No prior background in cybersecurity is needed.  Please Note: The camp will offer an industry-led Career Expo organized in collaboration with the Technology Association of Oregon, providing an excellent opportunity for networking and learning more about the field. This is expected to take place in Portland or Salem in the Fall. More information (date, time, location) will be sent to the Camp registrants closer to the event.

title: Pre-College
subtitle: Rice
raw_text: Rice is a community of curious thinkers, passionate dreamers and energetic doers who believe that improving the world demands more than bold thought and brave action. It takes unconventional wisdom. Our goal in creating Rice University's Precollege Program is to provide an experience for students ages 13+ that embodies these values. Our program is designed for high school students who wish to dive deeper into subjects that piques their interest, such as genome engineering, physiology, aerospace, law, and more. Each course features dynamic video lessons by renowned Rice faculty and access to mentors. Courses are available year-round, and the online format enables students to study anywhere, anytime, at their own pace. This flexibility allows students to take multiple courses and explore a variety of subjects. Upon successfully completing a course's capstone project, participants will earn a Certificate of Completion from Rice University.

title: UWM
subtitle: Future Success Program
raw_text: The Future Success Program is designed for high school students to enhance their academic skills and prepare for college. Participants engage in workshops and activities focused on personal development leadership and college readiness. The program aims to empower students to achieve their educational goals and succeed in their future endeavors.

title: University of Washington
subtitle: Cultivate Learning High School Internship
raw_text: This internship provides high school students with the opportunity to engage in educational research and gain hands-on experience. Participants will work closely with researchers and educators to develop skills in data collection analysis and project management while contributing to meaningful projects in the field of education.

title: Tufts University
subtitle: Tufts Summer Scholars Program
raw_text: The Tufts Summer Scholars Program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in academic research under the guidance of Tufts faculty. Participants will explore a specific topic and develop critical thinking skills while gaining hands-on experience in a university setting.

title: Business Immersion
subtitle: UCSD
raw_text: In their first class, students will break into teams and come up with an original business idea. Over the course of the entire program they develop this idea into a business that they will ultimately pitch to investors. Along the way, teams need to develop a marketing plan and financial projections. By using an experiential learning approach, students will quickly engage in the topic, and the instructor introduces the underlying theory and concepts as students tackle these issues while trying to build their business.  On the final day of the course the teams present their products to an expert panel of judges who provide professional and informative feedback to the students.

title: Health & Biomedical Camp
subtitle: Lebanon Valley
raw_text: Lebanon Valley College's Health and Biomedical Sciences Camp offers a week-long immersion in biomedical science for high school students. Participants explore topics such as anatomy, physiology, and molecular biology through lectures and laboratory work. The camp includes hands-on research projects and interactions with faculty and professionals. Students gain a deeper understanding of biomedical sciences and potential career paths. The program aims to foster a passion for science and prepare students for college-level studies.

title: CED Summer Institute
subtitle: UCB
raw_text: Summer [In]stitute is a fast track to launching your environmental design career. Explore the methods and theories driving the field, experience the culture of design and planning studios, and develop a portfolio for job and graduate school applications with the expert guidance of faculty mentors. Each program includes a lecture series, a design or planning studio, media workshops, and site visits. After fulfilling the program requirements, you'll receive a certificate of completion and credit on an official UC Berkeley transcript. All classes are held in Bauer Wurster Hall, CED's home on the UC Berkeley campus. International students are welcome and encouraged to apply.

title: Bentley University
subtitle: Leadership Academy
raw_text: The Leadership Academy at Bentley University is designed for high school students to develop essential leadership skills through interactive workshops and activities. Participants will engage in team-building exercises and gain insights into effective leadership strategies while exploring their personal leadership styles in a supportive environment.

title: High School Scholars
subtitle: UNL
raw_text: NCPA selects promising eighth graders from first-generation, income-eligible families to join a cohort of their peers (NCPA scholars). Throughout high school, scholars demonstrate NCPA's Pillars of Excellence — Knowledge, Character and Commitment — by participating in:

title: Tulane University
subtitle: Explorations in Architecture and Design
raw_text: This program offers high school students a chance to explore architecture and design through hands-on projects and studio work. Participants will engage in creative problem-solving and develop skills in design thinking while experiencing the vibrant culture of New Orleans.

title: College Edge: Summer
subtitle: Columbia
raw_text: In the College Edge program, students in grades 11–12 truly get the college experience by earning college credit as they learn alongside Columbia’s undergrad students on our Morningside campus. Students will also receive academic advisement and professional development opportunities. College Edge courses differ from our other pre-college programs in that students enroll in real college courses to earn credit—which means they will register for courses. When selecting course load, plan to spend two to three hours of study outside class for every hour spent in class.

title: Quantitative Skills Program
subtitle: SPARC
raw_text: SPARC's program offers a diverse range of classes and activities designed to foster critical thinking and personal growth. Classes include topics like cognitive biases, superforecasting, and statistical street fighting, often taught in small discussion-based groups. Activities range from board games and improv to negotiation workshops and estimation competitions. The daily agenda includes seminars, electives, free time, and evening speaker series, providing a well-rounded educational experience.

title: Laboratory for Laser Energetics
subtitle: UR
raw_text: The Laboratory for Laser Energetics (LLE) at the University of Rochester holds an annual summer research program for Rochester-area high school students who have just completed their junior year. The eight-week program provides an exceptional opportunity for highly motivated students to experience scientific research in a realistic environment. Students who are accepted into the program are assigned to a research project and supervised by a staff scientist or engineer at the Laboratory. These projects form an integral part of the research program of the Laboratory and are related to the Laboratory’s 60-beam OMEGA laser, one of the world’s most powerful fusion lasers, and the OMEGA EP laser, completed in 2008.

title: Summer Design Academy
subtitle: UMass
raw_text: The UMass Amherst Summer Design Academy provides an opportunity for high school students interested in architecture, landscape architecture, urban or interior design to learn more about these professions and experience the kinds of activities that take place in a university design program.

title: Unveiling the Sugary Armor of Mycobacterial Cells
subtitle: UMass
raw_text: Our competitive Research Intensives program places high-achieving high school students in professional working labs alongside distinguished faculty, graduate and undergraduate students. Research Intensive in Unveiling the Sugary Armor of Mycobacterial Cells: Its Impact on Cell Growth, Antibiotic Resistance, and the War Against Tuberculosis Pathogenesis (Morita Lab). Mycobacteria cause many diseases including tuberculosis and leprosy. The Morita lab uses techniques in molecular biology, biochemistry, cell biology, and genetics to decipher the mechanisms employed by mycobacteria that make them survive in our human body and persist even after a long antibiotic treatment. The students are expected to work on mutants of a nonpathogenic model Mycobacterium species to investigate how mycobacteria grow and survive under stress conditions. Students will learn skills in basic microbiology and cell biology.

title: Annual Art Competition on Weather
subtitle: Cool Science
raw_text:

enhanced_description: Cool Science is a National Science Foundation-funded initiative that hosts an annual art competition focused on extreme weather, challenging youth to express their scientific learning through the visual arts. Open to students in elementary, middle, and high school, the program asks participants to address specific challenge questions regarding climate change adaptation, urban heat islands, and environmental preparation. Submissions can be entered electronically or by mail, with winners receiving a fifty-dollar gift card and the opportunity to have their artwork displayed on public transit and at community exhibition celebrations. To support student entries, the organization provides a variety of online resources, including educational videos on heat transfer and conservation of energy, as well as access to mentors and specific judging criteria.

title: National High School Game Academy
subtitle: CMU
raw_text: The National High School Game Academy (NHSGA) allows disciplined, passionate, and dedicated high school students to experience video game development using current industry best practices. Sharing methods and paradigms used in Carnegie Mellon's Masters of Entertainment Technology (M.E.T.) graduate program, the NHSGA focuses on an innovative blend of hands-on team projects combined with in-depth traditional classwork, lecture and discussion. As a verification of competence, homework is assigned and evaluated as the student progresses through the curriculum. Designed to elevate a student’s rigor, working process, and discipline, the NHSGA prepares students for their college education. As a culmination of the six weeks, student teams create an original game prototype from pitch to final playable demo.

title: Congressional Art Competition
subtitle: US Gov't
raw_text: The Congressional Art Competition invites high school students to submit artwork for display in the U.S. Capitol. Participants create original pieces that represent their artistic abilities and perspectives. The competition aims to showcase young artists' talents and provide an opportunity for their work to be featured in a national setting. Winners receive recognition and have their artwork displayed in the Capitol for one year. The contest promotes artistic achievement and engagement with the arts.

title: ASU
subtitle: RISE Leadership Institute
raw_text: The RISE Leadership Institute at Arizona State University is designed to empower high school students through leadership training and personal development. Participants engage in interactive workshops and activities that foster essential skills for future success. This immersive experience promotes collaboration and innovation among diverse youth leaders.

title: NextGen High School Internship
subtitle: Emory
raw_text: The Department of Human Genetics at Emory University recognizes that our differences make us stronger. To deliver the highest quality of care, we need a team with a wide variety of experiential backgrounds. That's why we're actively recruiting learners, faculty members and staff from underrepresented-in-medicine groups, to help us improve health outcomes for all members of the diverse community we serve. Because there is a clear lack of underrepresented minorities (URM) at all stages of academic learning for science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields*, we are proposing to address this gap by initiating a paid summer internship program for high school students of all backgrounds in the metropolitan Atlanta area beginning in the summer of 2022. Students applying should have a demonstrated interest in advancing the reach of STEM education to groups that have been historically underrepresented in medicine.

title: Summer Stem
subtitle: Cooper Union
raw_text: Summer STEM is an opportunity to try engineering for the first time or to dive deeper into engineering team work. Each 3- or 6-week class covers college-level topics and activities completed by The Cooper Union undergraduates in their first or second year or explores student and faculty research projects. Current high school students in grades 9, 10, 11 and 12 can apply.  This selective program encourages all curious, compassionate, and college-interested students to apply regardless of prior experience.

title: International Linguistics Olympiad
subtitle: IOL
raw_text: The International Linguistics Olympiad (IOL) is a competition for high school students that tests their skills in solving problems related to linguistics and language. Participants analyze linguistic data and solve problems that require an understanding of language structure and function. The IOL aims to foster interest in linguistics and provide a platform for students to showcase their problem-solving abilities. It offers an opportunity for students to engage with complex linguistic challenges and gain recognition for their skills. Success in the IOL can lead to further opportunities in linguistics and related fields.

title: High School Summer Program
subtitle: MD Anderson
raw_text: The program introduces interested and qualified young Texans interested in an Allied Health career to a research environment and provides firsthand experiences in the varied career opportunities available at MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas, the nation's leading cancer research and treatment centers. Up to 10 students will be selected to participate in this 10-week program. Students selected for the program are given a rare opportunity to participate in a research project in one of the biomedical disciplines under the guidance of a full-time member of the MD Anderson faculty. Emphasis is placed on the importance of the basic principles that form the foundation for scientific investigation.

title: Computing Program
subtitle: Oak Ridge NGP
raw_text: The Next Generation  Pathways to Computing Program (NGP) affords rising high school juniors, seniors, and recent graduates in accredited high schools or home school programs in Anderson, Blount, Knox, Loudon, and Roane counties the opportunity to learn about foundational computer and computational science skills. Students will be mentored by ORNL research and technical staff and will gain valuable skills needed for successful careers in computing fields. Participants will have access to ORNL’s leadership-class facilities, including Frontier, the world’s most powerful supercomputer. With a focus on solving the world’s most challenging scientific and technical challenges, ORNL conducts basic and applied research to deliver transformative solutions to compelling problems in energy and security. ORNL’s Computing and Computational Sciences Directorate oversees an immense store of computing power, and its talented staff of computational scientists and mathematicians conduct state-of-the-art research and development in computer and computational sciences in support of the US Department of Energy’s (DOE’s) missions and programs.

title: PennRSSA
subtitle: UPENN
raw_text: The Penn Rising Scholar Success Academy (PennRSSA) is a free, college preparatory and career exploration program designed for high school students across Philadelphia. Students enrolled in School District of Philadelphia, public charter, and Archdiocese of Philadelphia high schools are eligible to participate in either of our two programs regardless of their academic record.

title: Summer Camp LLNL
subtitle: SAGE LLNL
raw_text: SAGE is a free, one-week summer residential camp for Northern California public high school students (age 14 – 17) from all backgrounds. The SAGE Mission is to engage curious and passionate students, and empower them to explore a wide range of possibilities for their future. The LLNL SAGE camp will be held July 7 – 13, 2024.

title: Pre-Law and Mock Trial Summer Academy
subtitle: Rutgers
raw_text: This one-week program taught by a distinguished member of the Rutgers Law faculty is designed for anyone who has an interest in the law and government, who is considering a career in the legal field, who currently participates in or may want to participate in mock trial competitions, or who wishes to hone public speaking and advocacy skills.

title: Pollinator Health and Ecology
subtitle: UMass
raw_text: Our competitive Research Intensives program places high-achieving high school students in professional working labs alongside distinguished faculty, graduate and undergraduate students. Research Intensive in the Pollinator Health and Ecology Lab (Adler Lab). The Adler lab studies how floral traits, including shape, size and rewards, affect pollinator health and pathogen transmission. More generally, we are also interested in how species interactions affect pollinator behavior and pollination. Students in the Adler lab will use a combination of field and lab experimental manipulations to answer their questions. Students will conduct individual or small group experiments to understand how pollen, nectar or other floral traits affect pollinator behavior, health and disease transmission, or will work on comparing transmission dynamics between different bee species.

title: Artificial Intelligence Academy
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: Today’s computing power and big data are driving the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI) at unprecedented speed, igniting a new historical moment between science, ethics, and politics. Through a combination of lectures, guest speakers, discussion sections, and project building, you will explore not only the science of AI from its beginnings to its future, but also take a deep dive into the ethics of AI-enabled automation and the global governance frameworks taking shape to regulate its use.

title: Synthetic Biology Competition
subtitle: IGEM
raw_text: The iGEM competition challenges high school and university teams to design and build genetically engineered systems using synthetic biology. Teams work on projects that address real-world problems and present their work at an annual competition. The program fosters innovation and creativity in biotechnology while providing a platform for students to showcase their research and development skills. iGEM promotes collaboration and interdisciplinary learning, with teams working on projects that span various scientific and engineering disciplines. The competition encourages students to explore the potential of synthetic biology and its applications.

title: Case Western Reserve University
subtitle: Youth Engaged in Science
raw_text: This program engages high school students in hands-on research experiences in cancer biology. Students work alongside researchers to develop scientific skills and gain insights into the research process. Participants also receive mentorship and guidance to foster their interest in STEM fields and future careers in science.

title: Earthquake Program
subtitle: Caltech
raw_text: In May to August of 2024, you’ll have the opportunity to be a High School Earthquake Fellow at Caltech’s Seismological Laboratory. Work with and learn from the leading earthquake scientists, researchers, engineers, and technicians in Southern California. This three-part program, comprised of 4-hours each day on 3 Saturdays in the Spring, 19 weekdays in the Summer, and 2 Saturdays at the End-of-Summer, provides current high school sophomores and juniors with instruction and experiences that help them gain the skills to succeed in university settings. All accepted Fellows will also receive a stipend, a computer, and transportation to a field experience. By the time the fellowship is completed in August 2024, Fellows will have learned the basic science of earthquakes, computer skills such as recording data and plotting the results, critical thinking skills to analyze the data, and gained exposure to the geology of Los Angeles, experience of the research process, public speaking and poster presentation skills.

title: SCUDEM - SIMIODE Challenge
subtitle: Qubes
raw_text: The SCUDEM (SimClim Urban Design and Engineering Modeling) competition invites students to develop urban planning and design models using climate data. Participants work on projects that address environmental and urban challenges. The competition aims to foster innovation in urban planning and climate science. Winners receive recognition and awards for their models. The contest supports the development of skills in environmental design and urban planning.

title: Rice University
subtitle: Tribomechadynamics Research Camp
raw_text: The Rice Initiative for the Development of Research (RIDR) provides undergraduate students with research opportunities in various STEM fields. Participants work closely with faculty mentors on innovative projects and gain valuable hands-on experience in a collaborative environment. This program aims to enhance research skills and foster academic growth.

title: Summer Internship
subtitle: Fermilab TARGET
raw_text: The TARGET Program is a highly competitive six-week summer internship opportunity for Illinois high school sophomores and juniors who have a strong interest and demonstrated an aptitude for physics, mathematics, computer science, and engineering. The program’s design combines both work and experiential learning. TARGET encourages high school students to undertake college study and pursue careers in STEM disciplines. Increasing the number of minorities (Black, Hispanic/Latino, Hawaiian/Pacific Islander, Alaska Native/American Indian) and women in science, engineering, and computer science is a program priority.

title: Summer Edge
subtitle: Rutgers
raw_text: SUMMER EDGE is Rutgers University-Newark's summer program designed for high-achieving high school students. Students who meet the requirements can take up to two program-approved courses (up to 7 total credits) for college credit this summer. High school students who are age 16 or above, with a minimum grade-point average of 3.0 are encouraged to apply for the Summer Edge program.

title: Environmental Sciences Programs
subtitle: UCD
raw_text: These courses offer high school students an engaging, experienced-based learning opportunity to explore the environment and biological sciences. Study at the world-class UC Davis campus with one of our summer pre-college programs for a hands-on approach to scientific exploration and a unique opportunity to learn from exceptional UC Davis faculty. We also offer interactive online courses, featuring project-based learning and role playing. These courses allow you to immerse yourself in realistic scenarios designed to develop skills in teamwork, critical thinking and problem solving.

title: Women's Technology
subtitle: MIT
raw_text: The MIT Women's Technology Program (WTP) is a rigorous four-week summer academic experience to introduce high school students to engineering through hands-on classes, labs, and team-based projects in the summer after 11th grade.

title: AI-Scholars Pre-College
subtitle: CMU
raw_text:

Pre-College Programs  ›  Academic Programs  ›  AI Scholars
AI Scholars
Your Summer, Your AI Journey!
Imagine a summer exploring artificial intelligence alongside passionate peers, guided by Carnegie Mellon’s leading faculty. AI Scholars is a fully funded, merit-based program for rising high school seniors to develop real-world skills, gain mentorship, and take the first step toward your future in tech. During this four-week immersive program, scholars will engage in classroom instruction, research projects, faculty lectures, and industry experiences, gaining real-world experience while exploring one of today’s most exciting fields.
Program Overview
As an AI Scholar, you will dive into college-level courses and weekly college prep seminars covering admissions, financial aid, and social-emotional wellbeing. Through project-based learning, you’ll explore computing and AI concepts while collaborating on hands-on group projects that tackle real-world challenges and culminate in a final symposium presentation. You’ll also connect with industry leaders, gain mentorship from faculty, and build lasting relationships with peers all while experiencing life on a college campus. A core value of the AI Scholars program is a commitment to an inclusive, equitable community where all participants feel valued and supported; scholars are expected to uphold this value and actively contribute to a culture of respect and belonging.
AI Scholars is a fully funded, merit-based program that brings together students from across the country to learn directly from CMU faculty, staff, and researchers. Thanks to generous support from foundations, corporations, sponsors, and donors, all program costs are covered, including*:
Tuition
Housing
Meal plans
Select program-related field trips and special events
*Limited travel assistance is available for families facing transportation barriers.
Program Schedule & Commitment
The 2026 AI Scholars program is a four-week residential experience at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Upon admission, you are required to reside in the CMU dorms for the full length of the program. Full program participation is required; students may not miss classes, lectures, or project time for other programs or obligations. Because of the immersive, hands-on nature of AI Scholars, participation in any concurrent summer program - virtual or in-person - is not permitted. Asynchronous online courses may be considered only with prior approval from program directors.
Core classes, guest lectures, group projects, workshops, and field trips are held Monday – Friday, 9 a.m. – 6 p.m.* Evenings may include office hours, homework, group study, and social activities. Weekends are free for field trips, on-campus clubs, and exploring the city of Pittsburgh!
*Class times may vary but typically end between 5 p.m. and 6 p.m. daily. 
Curriculum
Academic
Personal Growth
Hands-on Experience
AIS students at baseball game
Testimonials
My experience at Carnegie Mellon Pre College Programs was truly life-changing. Something I'll never forget. The program not only challenged me academically but also provided valuable learning experiences and chances for personal development fueling my interest in computer science and AI. Collaborating on projects, with encouraging classmates and professors helped me grow both professionally and personally. The lively campus atmosphere and strong sense of belonging made my time incredibly fulfilling and motivating solidifying my decision to pursue computer science at CMU for my studies. ~ Eli T., AI Scholars 2024
I’m blown away… this program has been an amazing experience for Vincent and it’s been a wonderful growth to see in him. He came back curious and limitless; daring to attempt impossible things and has not stopped asking “what if … ?” instead of stating “No, because….” ~ Anonymous (Parent), AI Scholars 2023
Hear more from our students and families here!
Students working on project
Age and Grade
Age: You must be 16 years of age by June 20, 2026.
Grade: To be eligible for AI Scholars, you must be between your 11th and 12th grade years in high school during the summer of 2026.
Please read the Eligibility and Application Requirements for complete eligibility details. 
Students walking on campus
Financial Need
AI Scholars (AIS) utilizes a holistic application review and admissions process, looking at the full application and selecting program participants based on a combination of factors. Because participants are fully funded, demonstration of financial need is one of these factors. There is no option for participants to pay out of pocket tuition fees for this program, and documentation of financial need is required for application submission. Documentation includes either tax documents or a completed NACAC Application Fee Waiver signed by your high school guidance department. Examples of demonstrated financial need can be found here.
Please reach out to the AIS Program Director, Natalie Hatcher, with questions.
All applicants who meet the eligibility requirements will be considered.
Is this program only for students with financial need?
AIS student presenting
Questions?
For questions related to the Pre-College AI Scholars curriculum, contact Program Director Natalie Hatcher.
Learn more through our recorded presentations and FAQ events. 
Statement of Assurance
Carnegie Mellon University does not discriminate in admission, employment, or administration of its programs or activities on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, disability, age, sexual orientation, gender identity, pregnancy or related condition, family status, marital status, parental status, religion, ancestry, veteran status, or genetic information. Furthermore, Carnegie Mellon University does not discriminate and is required not to discriminate in violation of federal, state, or local laws or executive orders.
The university’s Discriminatory and Sexual Misconduct Policy contains grievance procedures that provide for the prompt and equitable resolution of Complaints alleging any action which would be prohibited by this Policy.
Inquiries concerning the application of and compliance with this statement should be directed to the Office for Institutional Equity and Title IX, Carnegie Mellon University, 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, telephone 412-

enhanced_description: AI Scholars is a fully funded, merit-based residential program at Carnegie Mellon University designed for rising high school seniors who are at least sixteen years old to explore artificial intelligence through an immersive four-week experience. The program features a rigorous academic curriculum including college-level courses, faculty lectures, and hands-on group projects that culminate in a final symposium presentation. Beyond technical skills, participants receive mentorship from industry leaders and attend college preparatory seminars covering admissions, financial aid, and social-emotional wellbeing. Admission is based on a holistic review process that requires demonstrated financial need, and the program covers all major costs such as tuition, housing, and meal plans. Participants must commit to full-time engagement in all scheduled activities and are prohibited from participating in any concurrent summer programs to ensure a focused, inclusive community experience.

title: Precollege Summer Institutes
subtitle: UCLA
raw_text: As the only official academic precollege programs offered by UCLA, Precollege Summer Institutes provide motivated and driven high school students the opportunity to earn college credit in one to three weeks while advancing their academic career and abilities in an area of study of their interest. Through co-curricular components including hands-on projects and performances, field visits, and guest lectures, students receive a comprehensive and immersive study of their chosen subject that goes beyond classroom instruction. Our Precollege Summer Institutes are open to high school students from around the world. We invite you to join our diverse and inclusive UCLA community full of respect, ideas, and optimism.

title: SAIS Summer Programs
subtitle: JHU
raw_text: Each summer, the school welcomes visiting students and working professionals to explore the world of international relations through courses and certificate programs. Whether you seek to build professional skills in a graduate certificate, complement an internship, or prepare for graduate school, you will be inspired by world-renowned faculty known for their academic and practical experience and build a network of talented classmates working across sectors and industries.

title: Summer Language Institute
subtitle: UMD
raw_text: Make progress and earn UMD credits through flexible 3- or 6-week sessions. Learning options include in person or online. Current UMD students simply register. All other students must first apply. Offered through the School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures in the College of Arts and Humanities, the Summer Language Institutes (SLI) features in-person learning with Beginner, Intermediate, and Advanced level training.

title: Science of Smart Cities
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: Science of Smart Cities (SoSC) introduces students to topics in engineering, computer science, and technology to make cities more sustainable, efficient, and safer. Working in teams, students design projects using what they learn about electronics and circuitry, coding, microcontrollers, sensors, and other hardware. During final presentations, students demonstrate how their project creatively provides a solution to a real-world challenge.

title: Auburn University
subtitle: Engineering Summer Camp
raw_text: This summer camp offers high school students hands-on engineering experiences through various activities and projects. Participants will explore different engineering disciplines and work collaboratively to solve real-world challenges while developing critical thinking and teamwork skills.

title: TCNJ
subtitle: Camp Innovate and Investigate
raw_text: Camp Innovate and Investigate is a summer program designed for high school students to explore science and engineering through hands-on activities and experiments. Participants will engage in collaborative projects and gain valuable skills while working alongside experienced educators and professionals in a supportive environment.

title: SARAS
subtitle: Stony Brook
raw_text: SARAS is a 3-week, summer program designed to heighten the awareness of High School and Undergraduate students in many aspects of Biomedical Science. The program has been offered since 2004.

title: University of Georgia
subtitle: UGA Young Dawgs Program
raw_text: The UGA Young Dawgs Program is designed for high school students to gain hands-on experience in various fields while working alongside UGA faculty and staff. Participants engage in meaningful projects that enhance their skills and knowledge in a supportive environment fostering personal and academic growth.

title: Summer Session
subtitle: UCLA
raw_text: UCLA Summer Sessions offer a wide range of courses, both online and in-person, allowing students to advance their academic goals, explore new subjects, or satisfy prerequisites. With flexible scheduling options, the program caters to current UCLA students, visiting students from other universities, high schoolers, and international students. Additionally, participants can benefit from UCLA's extensive resources, including libraries, laboratories, and online tools. The sessions are designed to provide a comprehensive learning experience with access to esteemed UCLA faculty and the vibrant campus community. Financial aid and scholarships may be available to help offset costs, making it an accessible option for continued education during the summer.

title: Pomona College
subtitle: RISE Research Internships in Science and Engineering
raw_text: RISE offers high school students the chance to engage in hands-on research in science and engineering fields. Participants work closely with faculty and graduate students on innovative projects while developing valuable skills and gaining insight into academic research.

title: Design Discovery Program
subtitle: UVA
raw_text: Design Discovery is a 6-day summer program hosted by the UVA School of Architecture that invites high school students of all backgrounds to unlock their creativity through design-thinking. Each session will demystify design and introduce it as an empowering way of seeing and working in the world. Participants will operate in both academic and real-world settings: a learning-through-making workshop series, an architecture firm visit, and a tour of an active construction site. An ‘I See Me’ lunch and learn series features conversations with a diverse cross-section of UVA alumni, faculty, and students. All youth participants will have access to dedicated workspace in our studio environment with appropriate safety orientation to our robust Fabrication Lab. Each program session culminates in a celebratory exhibit with food, families, and friends.

In this section
Hoya Summer High School Information Session Webinar
Wednesday, Nov. 19, 4–5 p.m. ET

This information session will review our three programs: Non-Credit Academies, College Prep, and Summer College. We want to ensure that our prospective students are confident in their choice while planning their summer at Georgetown. We will provide an overview of each program and its respective application processes.

Register for the Webinar
In the American Politics Academy, you’ll take an in-depth look at the three branches of government through a blend of lectures and debate exercises. You’ll learn about the important role that political parties, public opinion, and special interest groups can have on shaping political behavior and decisions while exploring how America’s changing culture impacts political movements and, ultimately, federal, state, and local policies. You’ll have opportunities to hear from key elected officials, Capitol Hill staff, lobbyists, and policymakers who will join class discussions on congressional campaigns, legislative priorities, and emerging national issues.

Program Dates
June 7–13, 2026

Program Format & Subject Areas
As a student in the American Politics Academy, you'll spend your day immersed in a blend of lectures, activities, and group discussions. Throughout the week, you'll have the opportunity to explore the following subject areas:

Congress and the presidency
The impact of the judiciary
The parties in Congress
Public opinion
Interest groups
Foreign policy
Tax and spend authority
How You'll Benefit
#1
Hear from key elected officials and Capitol Hill staff, lobbyists, and policymakers.
#2
Participate in congressional simulations, putting your knowledge into practice.
#3
Explore contemporary political debates with expert faculty, enthusiastic mentors, and talented peers who share your interests.
#4
Receive a Certificate of Participation upon successful completion.
Having the chance to experience once in a lifetime opportunities and getting to meet people from around the world made it so I got to really experience what college life was like.

At the end of the day, you'll have opportunities to participate in optional cocurricular events, free time, and residential living activities until curfew.

enhanced_description: The American Politics Academy is a one-week pre-college program for high school students that provides an in-depth exploration of the three branches of government, political parties, and the impact of public opinion on federal, state, and local policies. Participants engage in a rigorous schedule of lectures, debate exercises, and congressional simulations while hearing directly from guest speakers such as elected officials, Capitol Hill staff, and lobbyists. The curriculum covers diverse subject areas including foreign policy, the judiciary, and tax and spend authority, culminating in a capstone project and the award of a Certificate of Participation upon successful completion.

title: Accelerated Learning Program (ALP)
subtitle: UW Madison
