Apply to Pomona College Academy for Youth Success
Expand the video: 20 years of Pomona College Academy for Youth Success (PAYS): Check out this video celebrating the 20 years of the Pomona College Academy for Youth Success (PAYS) program!
20 years of Pomona College Academy for Youth Success (PAYS)
Check out this video celebrating the 20 years of the Pomona College Academy for Youth Success (PAYS) program!

Participants will be selected by a committee of Pomona College faculty, staff and students. The selection committee will consider every part of the application and make recommendations based on academic potential. In some cases, the selection committee will request to interview an applicant. Each year the committee admits 30 participants. New applicants must be currently enrolled in 9th grade, attend high school in Los Angeles County, Orange County, Riverside County, San Bernardino County or Ventura County, and vaccinated for COVID-19.

Eligibility
 To be eligible to apply, you must: 

Reside within one of our five local counties (Los Angeles County, Orange County, Riverside County, San Bernardino County or Ventura County)
Be a current 9th grade student
Other factors taken into consideration include:

First-Generation College-Bound student
Low-Income (Qualifies for Free-Reduced Lunch)
Currently taking Geometry OR Integrated Math II
Selection Process
The dates for the 2025 selection process are as follows:

Application Opens: Monday, November 10, 2025
Application and Transcript Deadline: Monday, February 23, 2026
Recommendation Form Deadline: Monday, March 2, 2026
Notification of Decision: Friday, April 17, 2026
Summer Program Dates
Residential Dates: Sunday, June 21- Friday, July 17, 2026

 Scholars Selfie
Photo by Jeanine Hill. PAYS Scholars taking a selfie during our program picture day.
 

**Academic Year Calendar will be shared upon admission.**

**In order to participate in the residential experience, admitted students must show proof of COVID-19 vaccination (including Booster).**

Cost
All aspects of PAYS programming are of NO COST to PAYS scholars. Pomona College covers all costs including housing, food, activities, and transportation to field trips. Students will only be required to bring basic school supplies, such as pencils and paper. 

Application Information
A complete application will include the following materials. It is preferred that the application be completed online. However, a paper copy (found below) may be scanned and emailed, mailed in one envelope, OR faxed to (909) 607-8006.

Online New Student Application OR Paper New Student Application
Two Completed Essays (500 words MAX each)
Essay 1: Tell us about your educational experience so far; what are your thoughts about it? What would you change? Why? Is there anything you would keep the same? Why? You may choose to consider your educational experience in comparison to others in your school, your school district, and/or the country.
Essay 2: We are interested in learning more about the factors and challenges that have influenced your life, aspirations, and achievements. How did these factors and challenges affect you and what have you learned from them? Share with us how these experiences have made you into the person you are today.
OPTIONAL Essay 3: Is there a specific background, life experience, perspective, passion, character, and/or interest that is so meaningful that your application would be incomplete without it? We’re all ears! Feel free to share that with us! (350 words max)
OPTIONAL Additional Information: Is there something that is not on your application that you would like to share? You may use the space below to provide any additional information. Examples include, but are not limited to extenuating circumstances, personal website/blog/YouTube channel, artwork, or music recording, etc. If you need more space, please attach a separate sheet of paper to this application (350 words max). Share or email materials to PAYS@pomona.edu.
Transcript of current academic year
Official copy is preferred, but not required
May be emailed or mailed by applicant or counselor
If emailed, include in subject line: FirstName_LastName_HighSchool_PAYSTranscipt
Two Recommendation Forms
One must be completed by a core subject (Math, History, English, Science) teacher
The other can be completed by teacher, counselor, coach, community leader, etc.
Please include recommender contact information in online application and they will receive the recommendation form via email
If your recommender prefers a paper recommendation form, you can use the Paper Recommendation Form
Applicants may submit up to a total of 4 letters of recommendation
Please submit any physical documents by email, fax, OR mail, as follows: 
Email: PAYS@pomona.edu
Fax: (909) 607-8006

Mail:
Draper Center for Community Partnerships
Pomona College
Attn: PAYS
735 N. Dartmouth Ave. Claremont, CA 91711
Phone: (909) 607-1810 

For questions or to have a full paper application mailed to you, please contact us at (909) 607-1810 or PAYS@pomona.edu

enhanced_description: The Pomona College Academy for Youth Success (PAYS) is a no-cost residential program that selects 30 participants annually based on their academic potential and commitment to future college success. Eligible applicants must be current ninth-grade students who reside in Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, San Bernardino, or Ventura counties and provide proof of COVID-19 vaccination. The selection committee prioritizes first-generation college-bound students and those from low-income backgrounds, particularly those currently enrolled in Geometry or Integrated Math II. To apply, students must submit an application featuring two essays, an academic transcript, and at least two recommendation forms, including one from a core subject teacher. While the college covers all major expenses such as housing, food, and activity transportation, scholars are only responsible for providing their own basic school supplies.

title: Speech & Debate Tournament
subtitle: National Speech & Debate
raw_text: The National Speech and Debate Association's National Tournament in 2024 provides a platform for high school students to showcase their skills in speech and debate. Participants compete in various categories, including public speaking, debate, and oral interpretation. The tournament is a culmination of the year's competitive events and features top students from across the nation. It aims to foster effective communication skills, critical thinking, and public speaking abilities. The event offers opportunities for students to gain recognition and experience in a competitive setting.

title: Research Experience for High School Students
subtitle: Vanderbilt
raw_text: The Research Experience for High School Students (REHSS) Program is a program for current Interdisciplinary Science and Research students. Here, students complete an intensive, 6-week scientific research internship at Vanderbilt University, centering on full immersion in a Vanderbilt University or Vanderbilt University Medical Center research lab. Students engage in an independent research project under the mentorship of a research faculty member at Vanderbilt. These rising high school seniors should show an interest in a career in the fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM).

title: ACE
subtitle: Stony Brook
raw_text:
Skip Navigation

Accelerated College Education (ACE)
ABOUT
HOW TO REGISTER
COURSES
PARTNER HIGH SCHOOLS
FAQ
CONTACT
Earn College Credit at Your High School
Make your current courses count for more
Stony Brook's Accelerated College Education (ACE) program enables you to earn college credit on an official SBU transcript for courses you're already taking. No standardized tests are required!

High schoolers who enroll in ACE can:

Get a head start on college
Earn credits from New York's #1 public university
Save on future tuition costs
Enjoy a lighter college course load
Explore more electives and extracurriculars as a university student
Transfer earned Stony Brook credits to many other institutions
Once you register for ACE, you'll start receiving college credit for your ongoing high school coursework. Your final grade in the class will be reflected on your SBU transcript. Unlike other methods of earning college credit in advance, ACE involves no big exams or projects outside of class.

SPRING 2026 REGISTRATION
You can register for Spring courses beginning on February 2. Check here for the link!

enhanced_description: Stony Brook University’s Accelerated College Education (ACE) program allows high school students to earn college credit for courses they are already taking at their own schools. These courses are taught by approved high school teachers, and unlike other programs, ACE requires no standardized tests or additional projects outside of regular classwork. Participants receive an official Stony Brook University transcript where their final course grades are recorded, providing transferable credits that can save on future tuition and lighten future college course loads. While these credits are especially transferable within the SUNY system, they are accepted by many other institutions, allowing students to explore more electives and extracurriculars once they reach the university level.

title: Summer Science Internship
subtitle: Arthritis Foundation
raw_text: The Summer Science Internship Program provides outstanding students with the opportunity to work in leading research and clinical laboratories under the supervision of worldrenowned physicians and scientists at the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF). Through this internship, students receive hands-on experience in the fields of rheumatology and immunology, with a focus on arthritis and related autoimmune diseases. Interns participate in either basic laboratory (bench) research or clinical translational/epidemiological (patient outcomes-oriented) research or bioinformatics (computational) research. This program is designed to encourage motivated students to pursue a career in scientific study and research with the ultimate goal of inspiring them to focus their research potential on arthritis and related autoimmune diseases. Many graduates of the Summer Science Internship Program have gone on to pursue successful careers in the fields of medicine and/or scientific research.

title: Fellowship Program
subtitle: Youth Bridge
raw_text: The heart of YouthBridge-NY is its two-year Fellowship program, where high school juniors and seniors from diverse backgrounds participate in intensive trainings on leadership and diversity. The fellowship kicks off in late August with an overnight orientation retreat, where participants get to know each other through team-building games, outdoor activities, and workshops on topics like diversity, social justice, and leadership. Throughout the first year of the program, first-year teen Fellows participate in skill-building workshops and team-based learning opportunities; second year Bridgers are immersed in experiential learning opportunities and mentoring with successful professionals.

title: Early College Credit Program
subtitle: UW Madison
raw_text: Qualified high school juniors and seniors may apply for admission to UW–Madison as a University Special student to enroll in up to two courses per term for which they may earn high school credit, post-secondary credit, or both. Read below about the options for high school students to apply and enroll as a University Special student to earn credit.

title: Biophysics Research
subtitle: JHU
raw_text: The Biophysics Research for Baltimore Teens (BRBT) program provides opportunities for Baltimore City high school students to experience hands-on biomedical research in a state-of-the-art research facility at Johns Hopkins University. BRBT paid internships are five days a week for a five-week period, from mid July to mid August. BRBT interns experience the excitement of scientific discovery in a high-tech teaching laboratory equipped with the latest in research instrumentation under the guidance of two full-time instructors. BRBT’s goal is to give the students confidence, mentorship, and know-how to excel in the research laboratory, and to give them a pathway to a career in biomedical research.

title: International History Olympiad
subtitle: IHO
raw_text: The History Olympiad is a competition that challenges high school students to demonstrate their knowledge of historical events and themes. Participants engage in exams and essays that test their understanding of history and historical analysis. The Olympiad aims to foster a deeper appreciation for history and encourage students to excel in historical studies. It provides a platform for students to showcase their historical knowledge and gain recognition for their achievements. The competition supports students in developing critical thinking and research skills related to history.

title: VCU
subtitle: Dental Careers Exploration
raw_text: This program offers high school students an opportunity to explore careers in dentistry through hands-on activities and interactions with dental professionals. Participants will learn about dental health and the educational paths required to pursue a career in this field.

title: Summer Online Program
subtitle: UChicago
raw_text: This summer, take an undergraduate-level course with high school students from all over the world, from wherever you are! Summer Online allows students to explore subjects like biochemistry, art, quantitative finance, and more through five-week courses involving real-time interaction, engaging class discussions, and group projects. Each course has been especially designed to make the most of online resources and activities, and deliver the academically rigorous experience synonymous with UChicago.

title: Summer Scholars Program
subtitle: Rutgers
raw_text: The Rutgers Summer Scholars Program offers high school students (aged 16+) the unique opportunity to immerse themselves in college-level academics at one of the nation's top research universities. This program offers online and in-person course options. Enrolled Summer Scholars students can take two program-approved courses for credit. In these courses, students will experience a genuine university course with college-level coursework and undergraduate classmates led by Rutgers–New Brunswick instructors.

title: Life Sciences Research
subtitle: UCSD
raw_text: In partnership with Boz Institute, we will offer a unique science research learning experience. Our programs will involve field work, fundamental molecular biology topics, modern laboratory techniques, and relevant bioinformatics and statistical applications. Learn to synthesize life science fundamentals, review literature, formulate hypotheses and design experiments, collect and process samples, execute experiments, analyze data, and showcase your work through poster presentations attended by local scientists and industry leaders.

title: Writing & Culture
subtitle: CMU
raw_text: The idea of the attic-bound creative is a myth. Regardless of the medium, filmmakers and writers live their lives out in the world, not hidden behind closed doors. In this program, students explore writing, film, and culture through traditional, historical, and contemporary lenses on CMU’s campus and throughout Pittsburgh. Over the weeks, students will produce a body of work anchored in digital poetics and short-form writing, film development and production, and preparatory materials setting a strong foundation in the humanities.

title: Online Summer
subtitle: Columbia
raw_text: Monday through Friday, students will join their virtual classrooms to refine their academic skills through a variety of activities—class discussions, debates, simulations, individual and group projects, Student Life workshops, and more. Through Columbia's online interactive learning platform, students across the globe can engage with one another through rigorous curricular instruction, inclusive student life activities, and informative college success events.

title: CCRI - Climate Change
subtitle: NASA
raw_text: Internships are educational hands-on opportunities that provide unique NASA-related research and operational experiences for educators and high school, undergraduate, and graduate students (age 16 and up). To learn more, visit https://intern.nasa.gov. Climate change has impacted all components of the environment, and the impacts on global lakes have been quite noticeable. There are over 100 million lakes on Earth (excluding those that are covered with glaciers), covering roughly 4% of the total land surface. Natural lakes and man-made reservoirs are essential sources of freshwater, and they provide inarguably important services to society. They are used for fresh drinking water, municipalities, recreational activities, and fisheries. Moreover, lakes play a major role in carbon sequestration and thereby are critically important for our planet. Many lakes have been desiccated by the adverse impacts of climate change, and their ensuing degraded water quality has led to major losses in economic and ecological value as they have now become significant societal and health risks. In addition to climate change desiccation, lakes are dying and degrading due to human mismanagement, point and non-point source pollution, and general loss. The extent and rate of global “lake-loss” is not fully understood. Therefore, many aspects of in-land water bodies require robust, comprehensive study and monitoring in order to achieve sustainable environments, habitats, economies, and agriculture. Spaceborne remote sensing observations with their unique spatial and temporal coverage have considerable capabilities for supporting investigations of the Earth system including in-land water bodies. This project, therefore, focuses on the application of satellite remote sensing and geographic information system techniques complimented by ground observations to study lakes and to provide insights about “lake-health” and about “lake-response” to the adverse impacts of climate change. Interns will obtain and analyze satellite data from geostationary and polar orbiting satellites such as the Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite-R Series (GOES-R), LandSat, ECOSTRESS, Sentinel 2A, the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS), etc.

title: Coding and Robotics Intern
subtitle: IALR
raw_text: The Institute for Advanced Learning and Research (IALR) offers an annual summer internship program to provide meaningful on-the-job training. The internship program provides real-world leadership development experiences in diverse career fields such as research and data analysis, public relations, human resources, AgTech research, coding and robotics, information technology and more. Candidates for IALR internships must be: a high school graduate with plans to attend college in fall of 2024; an undergraduate or graduate level college student; OR a recent college graduate, within the last 12 months.

title: Badger Precollege
subtitle: UW Madison
raw_text: What can young learners do at UW–Madison this summer? Just about anything. Badger Precollege offers an array of academic programs for students ages 7-18 — from advanced learning programs and STEM classes to music clinics and college readiness conferences. Whatever you choose, your student will enjoy the university’s outstanding facilities, resources, faculty and staff — all while getting to know the UW–Madison campus, pursuing their passions and meeting new friends. Financial assistance is available for most programs. International students are welcomed and encouraged to apply for our high school programs. Learn more about our international programs. We look forward to meeting your student soon!

title: University of Notre Dame
subtitle: Global Scholars Program
raw_text: The Global Scholars Program at Notre Dame offers high school students the opportunity to engage in a unique academic experience focused on global issues. Participants will develop critical thinking skills and cultural awareness through interactive coursework and collaborative projects with peers from diverse backgrounds.

title: College Bridge
subtitle: Northwestern
raw_text: Thanks to a partnership between the Chicago Public Schools and Northwestern University, we are pleased to admit 25 high school juniors from Chicago Public Schools to the College Bridge Program each summer. Students enroll in courses as part of the Northwestern Summer Session and students earn college credit for satisfactorily completed courses. Courses vary from three to ten weeks in length, and are offered online or on campus.

title: National Mock Trial Championship
subtitle: NHSMTC
raw_text: The National Mock Trial competition offers high school students the chance to participate in simulated legal cases, presenting arguments and evidence in a courtroom setting. Teams of students assume roles such as attorneys and witnesses, working together to build their case and argue in front of judges. The competition helps students develop skills in public speaking, critical thinking, and legal reasoning. It also provides an opportunity to explore the field of law and gain practical experience in legal procedures. National Mock Trial aims to inspire future legal professionals and enhance students’ understanding of the judicial system.

title: Leadership Scholars
subtitle: Sadie Nash
raw_text: Leadership Scholars is a semester-long program designed to help Nashers create their own post-secondary education and career plan and help them advocate for educational justice. Students explore issues of educational (in)justice, learn about past and present examples of student activism, and get a head start in their journeys beyond high school.

title: Summer Session
subtitle: Binghamton
raw_text: Looking to get ahead in your studies? Satisfy Gen Ed requirements? Whatever your academic goals might be, Binghamton University can help you reach them.

title: Research & Stats Camp
subtitle: UTAUS
raw_text: The University of Texas Research & Statistics Camp is for students who will have graduated from 8th or 9th grade by Summer 2024 and are interested in university-level research. In this five-week camp, students have the opportunity to explore UT while working on their own independent inquiry. Students take Research & Inquiry, Statistics, and Technical Writing to supplement their research endeavors.

title: UCIGATI
subtitle: Beam Virtual
raw_text: Beam Virtual is an interactive online program designed for high school students to explore various STEM fields through engaging activities and mentorship opportunities. Participants will gain insights from industry professionals and enhance their skills in a collaborative environment while working on real-world challenges.

title: Gear Up
subtitle: UNLV
raw_text: A high school diploma and a college degree are all within your reach. Set realistic goals today and achieve your dreams tomorrow. We’ll show you how. The mission of GEAR UP is to significantly increase the number of low-income students who are prepared to enter and succeed in postsecondary education. GEAR UP is designed to enable more young Americans to stay in school, study hard and take the right courses to succeed in college. The aim is to help communities create new or expanded school programs and provide educational opportunities for students.

title: Business Academy
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: Georgetown's Business Academy introduces you to the ins and outs of the business world. Combining investment challenges and group presentations with dynamic faculty lectures and case studies, our program prepares you with the practical skills and critical thinking abilities that will benefit you in your future academic and professional endeavors. You'll register for one of two distinct tracks: Business & Leadership or Global Business. In each track, you’ll gain valuable exposure to important business topics and methods of analysis while learning from Georgetown McDonough School of Business professors and leading experts in the field. Throughout the program, you'll also participate in business simulations that take you through the process of becoming an entrepreneur and starting a company.

title: University of Tennessee
subtitle: Evol10
raw_text: Evol10 is a pre-college program designed for high school students to explore STEM fields through hands-on activities and collaborative projects. Students will engage in innovative learning experiences and develop critical thinking skills while working alongside peers and mentors in a supportive environment.

title: Challenging Academically Talented Students
subtitle: UNH
raw_text: The Challenging Academically Talented Students (CATS) program is designed to prepare high school students for the next step in their academic journey at UNH by offering the ability to earn college credit, explore career pathways, and showcase academic abilities to college recruiters – all at a discounted tuition rate.

title: National French Contest
subtitle: AATF
raw_text: Concours is a national French language competition that evaluates high school students' proficiency in French through various challenges and activities. Participants demonstrate their language skills in areas such as speaking, writing, and cultural knowledge. The competition aims to promote the study of French and celebrate students' achievements in mastering the language. Concours provides a platform for students to showcase their French language abilities and gain recognition for their skills. It encourages students to deepen their understanding of French culture and language.

title: Swarthmore College
subtitle: Discover Swarthmore Fly Program
raw_text: The Discover Swarthmore Fly Program invites high school students to explore the college experience at Swarthmore. Participants engage in workshops campus tours and discussions with current students. This program aims to increase access and awareness of the college's offerings for underrepresented students.

title: Miami SAO
subtitle: Miami SAO High School Volunteer Internship Program
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to gain valuable experience in a professional environment. Participants will engage in various tasks that support the organization's mission while developing their skills and enhancing their resumes. Ideal for students interested in community service and personal growth.

title: Summer Internship Program
subtitle: Magee Womens
raw_text: Magee-Womens Research Institute (MWRI) is one of the largest institutes in the nation that focuses on reproductive biology, women’s health, and infant health. Our High School Summer Internship Program provides students with the opportunity to participate in basic, translational, or clinical scientific research with the goal of stimulating interest in biomedical research as a potential career. During the 6-week, 240-hour program (holidays included) each student will have the opportunity to work on their own research project under the guidance of an investigator and their staff at MWRI or Magee-Womens Hospital.

title: Marine Lab Pre-College
subtitle: Duke
raw_text: Located on the coast of North Carolina, the Duke Marine Lab offers a unique interactive experience for Pre-College participants. Students live and learn on site, with classes taught by experienced instructors and industry professionals while access to labs, boats, and other Marine Lab resources. Courses will include sustainability, conservation, marine biology and more.

title: Engineering Summer Academy
subtitle: Rutgers
raw_text: The Engineering Summer Academy at Rutgers University provides high school students with an introduction to aerospace, biochemical, biomedical, chemical, civil, computer, electrical, environmental, forensic, industrial, material science, mechanical and systems engineering disciplines and careers. Students will enhance their math and science skills by learning how to analyze and interpret data and use quantitative models.

title: Scholastic Press Association
subtitle: Columbia
raw_text: The Columbia Scholastic Press Association (CSPA) offers programs and resources to support student journalism and media. It provides workshops, training, and competitions for high school and college journalists. The CSPA aims to enhance the quality of student media through educational opportunities and recognition programs. Participants can earn awards and gain valuable feedback on their work. The association fosters excellence and innovation in student journalism.

title: Upward Bound
subtitle: Binghamton
raw_text: Thank you for your interest in Upward Bound at Binghamton University.  We help students reach their academic potential and college success!  Please read more about the application process and expectations below.  Applications are reviewed on a first-come basis throughout the year. So apply anytime!

title: Civic Engagement Leadership Academy
subtitle: UNLV
raw_text: The Civic Engagement Leadership Academy (CELA) educates middle and high school youth about the agency young people have to impact policy. Weekly sessions will focus on defining civic engagement, knowing your elected officials, understanding community needs, researching solutions to community issues, and taking civic action. The culminating activity will be a social action media campaign designed and executed by youth in the program. This program is designed and implemented in partnership with Teaching and Uniting Ladies to Inspire Positive Success (T.U.L.I.P.S.).

title: Experience in Research
subtitle: UCB
raw_text: Experiences in Research (EinR) is an internship program for high school students to gain hands-on experience with professionals at Berkeley Lab. Students spend six weeks over summer working directly on cutting edge projects alongside experts in STEM (Science Technology Engineering Mathematics) and STEM adjacent careers. Projects are focused around different aspects of STEM professions such as administration, science communication, data science, experimental research, and more.  Students will be able to express their interests and project preferences in the application process to develop skills in their preferred field. Students will NOT be allowed to directly contact mentors during the application submission process.

title: UAB
subtitle: UAB Pre-College Research Internship
raw_text: This program offers high school and undergraduate students the chance to engage in research projects under the guidance of faculty mentors. Participants gain hands-on experience in a research setting while developing critical skills and knowledge in the field of medicine.

title: UNR
subtitle: Student Researchers Program
raw_text: This program allows bilingual English-Spanish students to engage in research activities while collaborating with faculty and peers. Participants gain valuable experience in research methodologies and contribute to community-based projects that enhance their academic and professional skills.

title: Leadership Institute
subtitle: Brown
raw_text: All over the world, youth are advocating for change both locally and globally. Through the Brown Leadership Institute you’ll increase your understanding of complex social issues and your ability to advance social justice, no matter your current level of engagement. Through both methods of learning, you’ll meet students from around the world who are passionate about a wide variety of issues, including topics such as law and social movements, educational equity, restorative justice and activism. You will spend your days delving into compelling topics in a course of your choosing, actively engaging with your peers and instructor. As you grapple with complex problems and brainstorm possible solutions together, you will practice a collaborative model of leadership honing your skills in active listening, public speaking, problem-solving, conflict resolution and teamwork. Building on this new knowledge, you’ll develop an Action Plan you can take home and apply in your school or community.

title: Summer Research Program (SRP)
subtitle: Indiana University
raw_text: When you participate in a summer program at IU Simon Comprehensive Cancer Center, you’ll work directly with a mentor physician or researcher conducting studies in the most progressive areas of cancer research. You’ll gain exposure to a wide range of basic science, translational, and clinical research activities—and you’ll have great experiences and references to add to your CV.

title: Summer Healthcare Experience
subtitle: UCI
raw_text: The mission of the Summer Healthcare Experience is a career exploration and empowerment program designed for young students who are rising Juniors and Seniors in High School and interested in learning about careers focused on women's health, providing equitable healthcare and closing the gap in healthcare leadership disparity. The program also provides participants with the practical tools and mentorship to achieve their educational and career goals in healthcare.

title: Biotech Academy
subtitle: Rice
raw_text: The Rice Office of STEM Engagement offers a one-week enrichment academy that explores tools and technology used in the rapidly evolving biotechnology landscape, with labs and Rice University faculty and graduate student discussions. The Biotech Academy includes hands-on STEM activities and design challenges that are experiential and project-based. Activities include DNA extraction and analysis, micropipetting, bacterial transformation, and testing of the PTC gene, among others. Through hands-on activities students will learn how to use a growth mindset and critical thinking skills while also being exposed to various STEM paths, careers, and emotional intelligence by partnering with professionals as role models, mentors, and guest speakers.

title: Oakland University
subtitle: Experience OU
raw_text: Experience OU is a pre-college program designed for high school students to explore various academic fields through hands-on activities and engaging workshops. Students will have the opportunity to experience college life and gain insights into their future educational paths while developing new skills and making connections.

Regional Ambassadors 

We have found that the best way for students to learn about our program’s opportunities and resources is directly through their school. 

The goal of Advanced Science Exploratory Program’s regional ambassador program is to maximize accessibility of our content to students. 

Regional Ambassadors are exceptional students (grades 9-12) chosen to actively help partner high schools in their geographic region with ASciencePro. This will allow more schools, and therefore more students, to access the content and opportunities through our program.

Your effort as a Scientific Regional Ambassador could result in access to the following opportunities:

Acknowledgement on our program’s website
Signed Certificate of Excellence
Free registration to select seminars
1:1 Mentorship with a Scientist (30 minutes)
Opportunity to publish an Article Review in C&C Editorials, ASciencePro’s online journal
