enhanced_description: The Advanced Science Exploratory Program (ASciencePro) offers a Regional Ambassador program designed for exceptional high school students in grades 9 through 12 who are passionate about expanding scientific opportunities within their communities. These ambassadors serve as vital liaisons between the organization and local high schools, working to maximize student accessibility to various educational resources and program content. In recognition of their efforts, participants can receive a Signed Certificate of Excellence, website acknowledgment, and free registration for select seminars. Furthermore, the role provides exclusive professional development opportunities, including 30-minute 1:1 mentorship sessions with scientists and the chance to publish article reviews in the C&C Editorials online journal. Interested students can apply for this leadership position by submitting their school information and a statement of interest through the ASciencePro website.

title: Summer Research Internship
subtitle: Stanford SHTEM
raw_text: The Stanford Compression Forum is offering its annual summer internship program for the Summer of 2025. We are looking for passionate high school and early CC students interested in pursuing fun research projects over the summer. This internship is intended to provide early exposure to research transcending traditional disciplinary boundaries. Students will be grouped to multifaceted projects that will benefit from their existing interests and strengths, while exposing them to new areas. Projects will be mentored by students, faculty and staff of the Stanford Compression Forum and its affiliated organizations. Themes will span and combine the science of information and communication, engineering, the arts, linguistics, psychology, biology, neuroscience, computer science, technology, philosophy, and design, among other areas.

title: Sounds of New York City
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: SONYC is an introduction to the study of noise pollution, one of the topmost quality-of-life issues for urban residents in the United States and particularly in NYC. Students will be able to study the public health consequences of sound by sampling sounds, studying sound waves in local communities, building devices that make and monitor sound, and evaluating how pollution ultimately affects human well-being. Students will demonstrate the skills and knowledge they learn by creating actual smart city technologies that they present at an end-of-program expo.

title: Technician Education
subtitle: Fermilab TECHS
raw_text: The Technician Education for Careers out of High School is an apprenticeship for Illinois high school rising seniors who have a strong interest in learning technical skills that can lead to careers as technicians at Fermilab. You must be a junior at the time of applying. The program’s duration is 10 weeks each for two consecutive summers. During the first summer, apprentices will learn basic electrical and mechanical skills and will be introduced to careers at Fermilab. During the second summer, apprentices will work alongside lab technicians on tasks that support the lab’s science mission. Apprentices who complete the two-summer program will be qualified to apply for entry-level technician positions upon graduation from high school.

title: VSGC
subtitle: VASTS
raw_text: The Virginia Aerospace Science and Technology Scholars program is a hands-on learning experience for high school students interested in STEM fields. Participants engage in a variety of activities including team projects and simulations while working alongside professionals in the aerospace industry.

title: Design Lab Program
subtitle: UCSD
raw_text: This Design Thinking Bootcamp will focus on user research via the ethnographic methods of participant observation and the ethics of conducting research online and offline. Students will learn practical skills on how to conduct online interviews and focus groups, design surveys, and develop case studies ethically and effectively. They will also hear about schools that offer design anthropology curricula and potential jobs & career trajectories where ethnographic methods are in high demand. The most important takeaway from the class is the ability to have a new critical look at familiar things. Students will also be able to listen, emphasize, and understand individuals and communities, who might be very different from themselves.

title: Math Minutes Video Contest
subtitle: Mu Alpha Theta
raw_text: Mathematical Minutes is a resource provided by Mu Alpha Theta that includes articles, problems, and solutions related to mathematics competitions and advanced problem-solving techniques. It aims to offer enrichment and practice opportunities for high school students interested in math. The content often features challenging problems, detailed solutions, and insights into various mathematical concepts. Mathematical Minutes helps students prepare for math competitions and enhance their problem-solving skills. The resource is designed to support students in developing a deeper understanding of mathematics.

title: Aspirnaut Summer Research
subtitle: UMich
raw_text: The Aspirnaut Summer Research Internship Program at U-M strives to expand interest in basic science research by bringing high school students from under-resourced areas to U-M to become immersed in a hands-on science laboratory experience. We are recruiting students from select communities across Michigan — including rural and socioeconomically disadvantaged communities. High school student interns will spend six weeks on U-M's Ann Arbor campus working with a team of researchers in the life sciences. They will conduct their own research project, and gather results that contribute to cutting-edge research. At the end of the experience, our Aspirnaut interns will present their findings to peers and mentors.

title: Ignite Your Passion for International Law
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: If the U.S. legal system seems complex, imagine the intricacies of how laws work across an international landscape. In International Law: Protecting the World's Interests, you will explore how international law is created, how jurisdiction works, how international treaties are negotiated, and how international law is enforced. You’ll even break down a simulated case study on the war in Ukraine and complete a Final Capstone Project in which you will take on the role of advisor. This fascinating course is a great choice for anyone who aspires to learn about international law and its impact on the world.

title: Math Program
subtitle: Stony Brook
raw_text: The Institute for STEM Education (I-STEM) is a major interdisciplinary STEM education center on the campus and has established a wide range of academic year and summer activities for faculty, graduate students, undergraduates and K-12 students and teachers. I-STEM’s mission is to provide comprehensive, high-quality STEM education that advances knowledge in the field. We work collaboratively across all levels of the educational spectrum to recognize, attract, nurture and develop talent. We expect that our faculty and the graduates of our programs will be leaders in the STEM education field through their production of new knowledge; the publication of their research in the leading journals; their presentations at state, national and international conferences and their influence upon key STEM policy initiatives. We believe that a sustained commitment to excellence in STEM education is imperative for the university and the nation.

title: Mayo Clinic
subtitle: Arizona Orthopedic Internship Opportunities
raw_text: This internship provides high school students with the opportunity to gain hands-on experience in orthopedic surgery. Interns will work alongside medical professionals and gain insights into patient care and surgical procedures. This program is designed to foster interest in the medical field and enhance students' understanding of orthopedic practices.

title: MITE Summer Camp
subtitle: UTA
raw_text: MITE is a five-day summer camp for current high school juniors to discover engineering through participation in an engineering team project, hands-on activities and interactions with engineering students, faculty, staff and alumni. MITE is open to students with strong interests in engineering, science or math. Fifty students will be selected to attend each session. All students are welcome to apply and must reside in the United States. Those who have overcome socio-economic hardship or have had limited exposure to engineering courses in their high school are strongly encouraged to apply

title: IFAL
subtitle: NCSU
raw_text: IFAL is a unique week-long leadership development program for rising high school seniors interested in careers in agriculture. Emphasis is placed on career opportunities, emerging technology, citizenship and leadership development. Students will visit the schools of agriculture, tour research farms and explore university laboratories. They will visit agribusinesses, participate in leadership development classes, tour the General Assembly, and see the offices of North Carolina Farm Bureau.

title: CMIMC Math Competition
subtitle: CMU
raw_text: The Carnegie Mellon International Math Competition (CMIMC) invites high school students to compete in math problems individually and in teams. Participants solve challenging problems across various mathematical disciplines. The competition aims to promote mathematical excellence and problem-solving skills. Winners receive recognition and awards for their achievements. The event supports the development of advanced mathematical abilities and collaboration.

title: Neuroscience Immersion
subtitle: Stanford CNI-X
raw_text: The Clinical Neuroscience Immersion Experience (CNI-X) at Stanford University is an intensive summer program that generally follows a student’s sophomore, junior, or senior year of high school. Students attend a two-week (10-day) session which provides introductory exposure to fascinating topics in neuroscience, psychiatry and psychology plus an opportunity to complete a collaborative capstone project. During each session, students from across California, the country, and the world are exposed to the breadth of research found in the Stanford Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences. Through interactive seminars with Stanford faculty and researchers, students learn about principles of neuroscience, clinical neuropsychiatry, neuroscience research, psychiatric epidemiology, behavioral and social sciences, and more. CNI-X also covers topics important to young people, including professional and career opportunities in medicine and science, plus self-care strategies in the transition to adulthood.

title: Tufts University
subtitle: Business Programs for High School Students
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to explore business concepts and develop skills through interactive coursework and engaging activities. Students will gain insights into various business disciplines and enhance their understanding of the business world while collaborating with peers.

title: Project Success
subtitle: Harvard
raw_text: Project Success: Opening the Door to Biomedical Careers is a program for BOSTON and CAMBRIDGE high school students only, particularly underrepresented in medicine and/or disadvantaged students, to participate in paid, mentored, summer research internships at Harvard Medical School and its affiliated institutions. The program is augmented by seminars and workshops given by faculty and administrators, site visits, and career guidance.

title: Citizens Thinkers Writers
subtitle: Yale
raw_text: Read inspiring and provocative works of literature and philosophy. Explore fundamental questions about justice, politics, and human nature. Meet community leaders in New Haven and ask them how they view the big questions. Gain confidence discussing these issues in college seminars taught by Yale faculty, and get a head start in college-level writing. Make new friends while living in Yale dorms for two weeks of the summer before your junior or senior year in high school. Take advantage of help in preparing to apply to colleges.  Citizens Thinkers Writers is a free program open to rising juniors and seniors in New Haven’s public schools. We give preference to students who would be first in their families to attend a four-year college.

title: RPI
subtitle: Polymer Chemistry Research Experience
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in hands-on research in polymer chemistry at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. Participants will work closely with faculty and graduate students to explore various aspects of polymer science and gain valuable research experience in a collaborative environment.

title: Summer Scholars Program
subtitle: Dartmouth
raw_text: As a Dartmouth Summer Scholar, you will have access to a custom selection of cross-disciplinary, noncredit courses taught by Dartmouth instructors, including faculty and staff. Explore your academic interests and discover new passions. Develop your time management, critical thinking, and communication skills. Make lifelong friends and connections with other scholars. Learn from experienced instructors who are passionate about helping students succeed.

title: Red Hat Shelton Challenge
subtitle: NCSU
raw_text: Challenge yourself to lead! The Red Hat Shelton Challenge is a six-day, residential program built on the Shelton Leadership Center’s core values – integrity, diversity, social responsibility, and compassion – and is designed to help high school students enhance their capacities to become values-based leaders. This immersive program is designed to transform potential into real-world skills through mentorship, self-reflection, and shared discovery. Throughout the Shelton Challenge, students will immerse themselves in daily classroom sessions, where they’ll learn about and develop an array of effective leadership skills essential for leadership roles. These sessions foster dynamic discussions, peer reflection, and mentorship with Challenge Instructors, enhancing their leadership acumen through active engagement.

title: Research Intensive in Food Science.
subtitle: UMass
raw_text: Our competitive Research Intensives program places high-achieving high school students in professional working labs alongside distinguished faculty, graduate and undergraduate students. Research Intensive in the Food & Environmental Chemical Impact on Development of Obesity Lab (Park Lab). The current epidemic of obesity cannot be explained completely by the dietary, social and/or behavioral changes that have occurred over the past several decades. Simultaneously, there are emerging evidences that persistent organic pollutants are linked to excessive weight gain and altered glucose homeostasis. With this background, the current focuses of research are [1] discovering food bioactives that can help prevent obesity and [2] determining the potential causative environmental chemicals for obesity.

title: LSU Summer Scholars Program
subtitle: LSU
raw_text: LSU University College’s Summer Scholars is a seven-week summer bridge program that prepares under-represented students to make a successful transition from high school to the University. This summer experience offers students the opportunity to become adjusted to the academic, personal, and social challenges they may encounter at LSU. Students are provided with a structured environment conducive to building the fundamental skills necessary to enhance the likelihood of successful completion of a baccalaureate degree.  In addition to tutoring, students will attend academic and leadership development workshops, receive extensive academic counseling, and participate in social and cultural activities. Students selected as LSU Summer Scholars are awarded a summer only scholarship that covers tuition, housing, and a meal plan.

title: Summer Journalism Workshop
subtitle: Columbia
raw_text: The Columbia Scholastic Press Association (CSPA) invites print and online publication staff to take part in its 43rd Annual Summer Journalism Workshop, offered with both in-person and virtual options. CSPA offers a week-long, in-person workshop in June on the Columbia campus, as well as three distinct virtual sessions in July. The annual workshop is organized by CSPA and hosted by Columbia University. Each session offers sequences focused on either reporting and writing, editorial leadership, and design. New courses to be announced. The workshop is intended for secondary school students and teachers from schools in the U.S. and international schools following an American plan of education. Participation in the Workshop is open to all students and advisers from senior high schools, whether public, private, or faith-based. No junior high or middle school students are accepted, but advisers from these schools are welcome. Students must be entering into sophomore, junior or senior year in high school. Financial assistance is available for students who qualify.

title: Neuroscience Journal Club
subtitle: Stanford
raw_text: Scientific publications remain the key mechanism for scientists to communicate the results of their original scientific research and findings to the field of medicine.  The Stanford Neuroscience Journal Club was initiated by faculty members, Dr. Odette Harris in the Department of Neurosurgery and Dr. Reena Thomas in the Department of Neurology.  The intent of this group is to mentor high-school scientists in the critical analysis of a scientific paper and encourage participants to consider a career in the Neurosciences. Our once-per-month meetings offer students an opportunity to read and discuss scientific literature and newsworthy developments in the field of neuroscience in a low-pressure environment, with expert Stanford scientists. There are no coursework prerequisites for participation, just a curiosity for science and a desire to learn how to understand scientific literature.

title: International Biology Olympiad
subtitle: IBO
raw_text: The International Baccalaureate Organization (IBO) offers a rigorous academic program that includes a range of competitions and challenges for high school students. The IB program emphasizes critical thinking, global perspectives, and interdisciplinary learning. Students participate in various academic and extracurricular activities to develop a well-rounded education. The IBO aims to prepare students for higher education and global citizenship through its comprehensive curriculum. It provides a platform for students to engage in challenging and enriching educational experiences.

title: Stem Academy
subtitle: Oak Ridge ARC
raw_text: The Appalachian STEM Academy at Oak Ridge is an all-expenses-paid, residential program in Oak Ridge, Tennessee designed to provide a hands-on STEM learning experience for students and teachers located in the Appalachian region. In addition to research, the program promotes teamwork, college opportunities, and pride in the cultural richness and historical importance of the Appalachian region.

title: MSU
subtitle: OsteoCHAMPS
raw_text: OsteoCHAMPS is a pre-college program designed for high school students interested in exploring osteopathic medicine. Participants engage in hands-on activities and learn about the medical field through interactive sessions with professionals. The program aims to inspire future healthcare leaders and provide insights into the osteopathic profession.

title: Essentials of Leadership
subtitle: UPENN
raw_text: Essentials of Leadership prepares talented high school students to become leaders in the global economy. Through a curriculum of rigorous coursework and activities, students will build skills in emotional intelligence, problem-solving, interpersonal communication, and effective teamwork and collaboration. The program culminates in a simulated trip to Saturn, where small groups must navigate the obstacles of interstellar travel to achieve the goals of the mission.

title: Honors Summer
subtitle: Texas State
raw_text: The Honors Summer Math Camp (HSMC) at Texas State University is an intensive six-week residential program for high school students. It focuses on advanced mathematical concepts, original research projects, and enrichment activities. Students engage in courses, seminars, and projects guided by Texas State faculty. The camp has a history of producing award-winning research, and alumni have excelled in competitions like Siemens and Intel ISEF. Tuition is $6,000, covering room, board, and program costs, with financial support available through donations.

title: Discover Architecture
subtitle: Oklahoma State
raw_text: DISCOVER ARCHITECTURE is a summer workshop held at the Oklahoma State University School of Architecture in Stillwater, Oklahoma. The workshop is open to high school students who are interested in exploring careers in architecture and architectural engineering. Through a series of hands-on design projects students get firsthand experience with the architectural design process; allowing students to determine if pursuing a degree and career in architecture or architectural engineering is for them.

title: UCSF
subtitle: High School Intern Program
raw_text: The High School Intern Program at UCSF offers students the opportunity to work alongside scientists and researchers in a laboratory setting. Participants gain hands-on experience in scientific research while developing skills in critical thinking and problem-solving. This program is designed to inspire future careers in science and healthcare.

title: Trails AI
subtitle: UMD
raw_text: The TRAILS AI Summer Academy is a two-week long, nonresidential computer programming and artificial intelligence (AI) summer camp at the University of Maryland. Students will come away from the camp knowing how AI can be used to help people and an idea of what kinds of careers there are in AI. Accepted students will have to complete ~25 hours of asynchronous content prior to the start date. The camp will be offered to rising 10th, 11th, and 12th graders. Students will be exposed to personal growth, education, and hands-on experiences presented by faculty, guest lecturers, and University of Maryland students. This program intends to create a more inclusive and diverse field of artificial intelligence by targeting and serving underrepresented communities. Students will be given the opportunity to use artificial intelligence to address problems of a probabilistic and numeric nature. Participants will explore the field of AI through team projects, industry field trips, and presentations from guest speakers. There will also be opportunities to engage with faculty, staff and researchers who have been leaders in AI. Students will be exposed to a breadth of knowledge in the field with the goal of leveraging AI for social good.

title: THINK Summer Institute
subtitle: Davidson Institute
raw_text: Our three-week residential gifted summer program, located at the University of Nevada, Reno, is designed to meet the needs of high achieving students. We provide social connections with academically motivated peers, dynamic courses with the option to earn college credit, access to university resources, and memorable field trips and activities.

title: CityLab Biotechnology SummerLab
subtitle: Boston University
raw_text: DNA, Genes, and Drug Production focuses on the central concepts and skills of recombinant DNA technology as they apply to biotechnology. The use of green fluorescent protein (GFP) allows students to visualize the processes of gene expression, cell lysis, and protein purification. This is a one-week program.

title: Fashion Technology Summer Program
subtitle: UTAUS
raw_text: In this course, assignments focus on establishing fashion design principles through digital line design development techniques. Students develop introductory skills using Adobe Illustrator to produce coordinated fashion design presentations, flat sketches, mood boards, fashion editorial trend boards, marketing materials and portfolio layout techniques. Course assignments focus on establishing industry techniques and developing proficiency in creating fashion designs using Adobe Illustrator.

title: SPS High School Academy
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: The NYU School of Professional Studies High School Academy's Weekend Workshops focus on college and career readiness for high school students and allow them to explore professional paths while gaining skills and knowledge to enhance their college readiness. Weekend Workshops offer students a pre-collegiate experience and immerse them in exciting professional fields like financial technology, architecture, fashion design, law, and more. By participating, students will improve their academic skills and learn more about what college is like, how they can prepare, and what careers might interest them.

title: University of Maryland
subtitle: Pathways Program
raw_text: The Pathways Program at the University of Maryland offers high school students hands-on experience in robotics and engineering. Participants engage in team-based projects and develop skills in problem-solving and critical thinking. The program aims to inspire students to pursue careers in STEM fields through interactive learning and mentorship.

title: Student Documentary Competition
subtitle: C-Span
raw_text: StudentCam is a national video documentary competition for high school students that encourages them to create short films on current events or social issues. Participants produce documentaries that explore various topics, demonstrating their research, storytelling, and filmmaking skills. The competition aims to engage students in civic discourse and provide a platform for their voices on important issues. StudentCam offers opportunities for students to showcase their creativity and gain recognition for their work. It also encourages critical thinking and media literacy among young filmmakers.

title: USC
subtitle: Young Researchers Program
raw_text: The Young Researchers Program at USC provides high school students with the opportunity to engage in hands-on research projects under the guidance of faculty mentors. Participants will develop critical thinking skills and gain exposure to various scientific disciplines while collaborating with peers in a supportive environment.

title: Joy of Coding
subtitle: UMich
raw_text: The Joy of Coding program at the University of Michigan offers a hands-on, immersive experience designed to introduce middle and high school students to computer science. Participants engage in interactive coding projects, learn programming concepts, and develop problem-solving skills. The program aims to make coding enjoyable and accessible, fostering a passion for technology and innovation. It includes workshops, collaborative projects, and mentorship from university students and professionals. Overall, the Joy of Coding program seeks to inspire and equip the next generation of tech enthusiasts.

title: Summer Experience
subtitle: Coriell
raw_text: Running from July 17 through August 19, the Coriell Summer Experience for Students is a paid opportunity for high school and college students to work alongside world-renowned scientists and researchers and gain insights into careers in science or related areas. Through our four-week Summer Experience program, we offer a limited number of students an exclusive opportunity to be a part of the day-to-day research activities in dynamic research and biobanking environments, and we offer the possibility to experience biobank operations.

title: College Summer Studies
subtitle: HCSSiM
raw_text: HCSSiM is an intensive six-week encounter with college-level mathematics for talented and highly motivated high school students. It is demanding and expanding. Participants spend a major portion of each day actively engaged in doing mathematics (not simply learning the results of mathematics). HCSSiM students live in the dorms at Hampshire College in Massachusetts for six summer weeks, and study and play in its fields, woods, and academic buildings (not typically in that order). Typically, there are as many girls and non-binary students as boys.

title: Odyssey of the Mind
subtitle: OM
raw_text: Odyssey of the Mind is a creative problem-solving competition where teams of students tackle complex problems through innovative solutions. Participants work together to create original performances, designs, and presentations based on specific problem themes. The program encourages students to think creatively and collaborate effectively, developing both their problem-solving and teamwork skills. Odyssey of the Mind culminates in regional, state, and world finals, providing opportunities for students to showcase their solutions. The competition fosters creativity and critical thinking in a fun and engaging environment.

title: W. P. Carey School of Business
subtitle: Fleischer Scholars Summer Program
raw_text: The Fleischer Scholars Summer Program is a unique opportunity for high school students to explore business education through hands-on learning experiences and mentorship. Participants will engage in workshops and networking events designed to enhance their understanding of business concepts and career pathways.

title: Tufts University
subtitle: Tufts Research Experience Academic Year
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in hands-on research alongside Tufts faculty and graduate students. Participants will develop skills in scientific inquiry and gain valuable experience in a university research environment while exploring various scientific disciplines.

title: Science Training Program
subtitle: UF CPET
raw_text: The University of Florida Student Science Training Program (UF SSTP) is a seven week residential research program for selected students entering senior year and at least 16 years old by the program start date who are considering science, medicine, math, computer science, or engineering careers. The program emphasis is research participation with a UF faculty research scientist and his or her research team. Students interested in attending the UF SSTP must possess a high level of maturity, an ability to live and learn independently, a desire to work collaboratively, and a sincere interest in research.

title: Scholastic Art & Writing Awards
subtitle: Alliance for Young Artists
raw_text: The Scholastic Art & Writing Awards recognize and celebrate the artistic and literary talents of high school students. Participants submit works in various categories, including visual arts, writing, and digital media. The awards provide opportunities for students to gain national recognition and scholarships for their creative achievements. The competition aims to support and encourage young artists and writers. Winners receive accolades and support for further developing their talents.

title: Bentley University
subtitle: Wall Street 101
raw_text: This pre-college program offers high school students an introduction to finance and investment banking. Participants will learn about financial markets investment strategies and the skills needed for a career in finance. The program includes hands-on activities guest speakers and networking opportunities with industry professionals.

title: Hinton Scholars
subtitle: Harvard
raw_text: The Advanced Placement (AP) Biology Hinton Scholars Program is an after-school enrichment program designed to enhance students' understanding of the AP Biology Big Ideas framework. Components include: hands-on inquiry-based AP bio science labs, small group tutoring led by Harvard medical and graduate students, enhancement of students’ scientific communication skills, mastery of digital probeware tools, and access to Harvard lectures, conferences, researchers, and faculty, and career panel discussions in the biomedical sciences.

title: AI, Data & Ethics: Introduction to Public Interest Technology
subtitle: UMass
raw_text: Today’s world is complex and tech-driven. Emerging technologies offer new solutions but they can also introduce new or deepen existing problems. (The release of ChatGPT in December 2022 presents an important recent case study.) How do we make sure that we develop and implement technologies that not only solve the problems we face in a socially responsible way but also empower individuals and communities?

title: UTSA
subtitle: UTSA Citymester
raw_text: The UTSA Citymester program offers students a unique opportunity to engage in real-world projects that benefit the San Antonio community while earning academic credit. Participants will collaborate with local organizations and gain valuable experience in civic engagement and community development. This immersive program enhances both academic and professional skills.

title: Machine Learning Program
subtitle: Sunrise
raw_text: At Sunrise Technology we work on applying machine learning techniques to a wide variety of real world problems. These problems can range from high energy particle physics to consumer applications. Using cutting edge algorithms we aim to provide the best performance with the most reliability.

title: Fordham University
subtitle: STEP Summer Program
raw_text: The STEP Summer Program at Fordham University offers high school students the opportunity to explore various subjects through engaging classes and workshops. Students will develop critical thinking skills and gain insights into college life while enjoying a vibrant campus environment. This program is designed to inspire and prepare students for their academic futures.

title: Explorations in Biology
subtitle: UChicago
raw_text: Students will spend the first two weeks learning remotely and the final week of class on UChicago’s campus engaging in hands-on laboratory investigations. Students will learn about fundamental principles in biology and the logic of scientific reasoning and experimental design by considering sex as a critical variable that is often disregarded in basic and biomedical research.

title: University of Utah
subtitle: Step Up Program
raw_text: The Step Up Program is designed for high school students interested in healthcare careers. Participants engage in hands-on learning experiences and mentorship opportunities with healthcare professionals. The program aims to inspire students to pursue careers in medicine and related fields while providing valuable insights into the healthcare system.

title: Computer Engineering for Good
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: Computer Engineering for Good is a two-week program designed to teach high school students the basic principles and skills needed to create innovative applications for internet-connected technologies that address global challenges. The Computer Engineering for Good program redefines “solution” by focusing on the ways computers and engineering can be applied to address the disparity. Students will go through the process of analyzing real-world problems specifically using developing world technologies and then use Computer and Electrical engineering skills to implement a viable innovative “solution” that can ensure sustainability. During the program, students will have lessons on aspects of design conception all the way through implementation.

title: OSU
subtitle: Young Scholars Program
raw_text: The Young Scholars Program at Ohio State University offers high school students the opportunity to engage in academic enrichment activities and gain exposure to college life. Participants will develop skills in leadership and critical thinking while exploring various subjects in a supportive environment.

title: Summer Stem Academy
subtitle: Duke
raw_text: he Thomas Lord Department of Mechanical Engineering (MEMS) offers a 3-week summer intensive for high school students to establish a Tech Talent Pipeline for the Triangle.  This program is an immersive, hands-on experience that is centered in engineering design practice through active application of theory. tudents learn computer-aided drafting, advanced manufacturing techniques (3D printing, laser-cutting, microcontroller programming, electronics, and shop tools), project management, product design, technical communication through presentations and websites, and teamwork. Rising juniors and seniors in high school are closely mentored by graduate students, faculty, and staff as they identify a problem of social importance and develop solutions in our advanced fabrication facilities and laboratories.

title: Pre-Baccalaureate Program
subtitle: Barnard
raw_text: Spend the summer on Barnard's campus! Join Barnard faculty and students in the classroom and earn college credit through our Pre-Bacc program. For high school juniors and seniors, and gap year students. Students enroll in one 3-credit course taught by a member of Barnard's world renowned faculty. Courses are held on campus, run for 7 weeks, and are fast paced and rigorous. Outside of the classroom students are part of our Barnard community and will explore New York City, participate in college readiness workshops and career exploration panels.

title: Los Angeles Institute
subtitle: CLYLP
raw_text: The CLYLP Los Angeles Institute (LAI) was established in 2006 to inspire and motivate students from Southern California to become future leaders through public service.  Open to 50 students from Los Angeles County, the three-day institute offers an impactful program designed to develop students’ leadership potential and increase their knowledge of the region’s cultural and political landscape. Institute participants connect with education, business, political and community leaders and receive encouragement in their pursuit of post-secondary educational opportunities. Housing, meals and program materials are provided at no cost to the participants or their families.

title: Internship Program
subtitle: LANL
raw_text: The High School Internship Program provides qualified New Mexico high school seniors the opportunity to develop skills and gain work experience while receiving exposure to a variety of career fields. Internships are available in both STEM and other career fields such as business or operations support. This applies to HS seniors and rising seniors.

title: SEES STEM Enhancement in Earth Sciences
subtitle: UTAUS
raw_text: NASA and The University of Texas at Austin Center for Space Research Summer Intern Program is a nationally competitive STEM program for high school students. The program provides selected students with exposure to Earth and space research. Interns will learn how to interpret NASA satellite data while working with scientists and engineers in their chosen area of work. Scientists and Engineers at UT/CSR are conducting NASA supported research on astronomy, remote sensing, and space geodetic techniques to help understand Earth systems, natural hazards and climate science. Additional research in engineering, astronomy, and planetary science will be available through Subject Matter Experts. This summer UT/CSR will support a summer intern program where interns will complete distance learning modules prior to July 1 and work remotely June – July 6,  guided by project mentors. The on-site internship for 11th graders will be July 7 – July 20, 2024. The on-site internship for 10th graders will be July 27 – August 4, 2024. Housing, meals, and local transportation will be provided for those selected. A limited number of travel scholarships to Texas are available. Virtual internships vary by project and timelines are listed in the project description. The SEES summer intern program will allow interns to view and investigate NASA remote sensing data, mission design, analysis of ice sheets, Earth’s gravity field, and other observations while being mentored by project scientists.

title: Imagine Cup
subtitle: Microsoft
raw_text: The Imagine Cup is a global technology competition organized by Microsoft, encouraging students to create innovative solutions using technology. Participants work on projects that address real-world challenges in various categories, including software development and artificial intelligence. The competition provides mentorship, resources, and opportunities for networking and recognition. Winners receive prizes and support for further development of their projects. The Imagine Cup aims to inspire and empower the next generation of tech leaders.

title: MEEP
subtitle: American Museum
raw_text: Through our comprehensive learning program, interns develop the skillful art of initiating engaging science conversations through our interactive and reflective workshops. MEEP interns initiate science discussions with our Museum’s visitors using the halls as a launchpad. They go beyond conveying mere facts to support our people in fostering a deeper understanding and connection to the science content in our exhibition spaces.

title: HSHP
subtitle: MSU
raw_text: Welcome to the website for the Michigan State University High School Honors Science/Mathematics/Engineering Program (HSHSP). I (Gail Richmond) am pleased to have served as Director of this outstanding research program since 1988. Its purpose is to provide students from across the U.S. and territories who are entering 12th grade with the opportunity to engage in intensive research work over a seven-week period and to interact with peers who come from diverse backgrounds but who share a love of science and/or mathematics.

title: NSTI Summer Camp
subtitle: Oklahoma State
raw_text: Registration includes morning refreshments, lunch, all STEM supplies, and a shirt. Currently, this camp is full. If you wish to join our waitlist, please fill the form below.

title: Emerging Rural Leaders I
subtitle: UChicago
raw_text: What does it mean to be a “leader” to you personally? How does one choose to be a leader? How can you create a better future for yourself and your community by leading with courage, capacity, and wisdom? In this one-week introductory course, students will learn about the importance of leadership and civic discourse from a variety of academic and social perspectives.

title: Virtual "Processing" Camp
subtitle: Oregon State
raw_text: Have you ever wanted to learn to program a computer without a lot of the jargon and buzzwords? Have you especially wanted to use it for loops, swirls, colors, and painting? Well, then, this opportunity is for you! This course is a non-threatening introduction to programming a computer for all-things-visual. We will learn to program in a simple "real language" called Processing (http://www.processing.org). We will use it for both 2D and 3D. We will use it for static pictures, painting, and animation. Programming this way will be fun, creative, and will have a beauty that will surprise you! Please note: please make sure that you can access Processing on your device by either downloading the software (http://www.processing.org) or by using the online version (https://editor.p5js.org) before signing up for this camp.

title: Clinical Summer Internship
subtitle: Stanford CSI (Fall)
raw_text: Stanford CSI brings together curious learners from differing backgrounds to actively engage in the exploration of the art and science behind world-class medicine. Discover, contribute and make meaningful connections and friendships while working alongside dedicated and dynamic Stanford medical students, residents and faculty, who are all eager to share the joy they have found in medicine.

title: Law Summer School
subtitle: UCB
raw_text: Law and Trial Advocacy Summer School is delivered on campus at UC Berkeley and provides students with a broad introduction to the theory and practice of law. It will equip students with a strong set of logical and argumentative skill through legal case studies and a Mock Trial Simulation, teaching them how to develop, argue and win their case. Gain insight into Criminal and Civil Law, while exploring facets of Business Law, Contract Law, Ethics and Human Rights. Experience the legal process and learn about evidence, case preparation, oral arguments, cross-examination and witness preparation as students grow their knowledge of the legal profession. Strengthen critical thinking, communication and rhetorical skills as students compete in the Mock Trial Simulation.

title: University of Denver
subtitle: Pioneer Prep
raw_text: Pioneer Prep is a summer program for high school students designed to enhance their academic skills and prepare them for college. Participants engage in interactive learning experiences and receive guidance from faculty members. The program also includes college readiness workshops and opportunities for personal growth.

title: UCLA Health
subtitle: UCLA BrainSPORT Internship
raw_text: This internship provides high school students with hands-on experience in neurosurgery and sports medicine. Participants will learn about brain health and injury prevention while working alongside medical professionals in a dynamic environment. The program aims to inspire future careers in medicine and healthcare.

title: Business Competition
subtitle: DECA
raw_text: DECA is an organization that offers competitions and activities for high school students interested in business, marketing, and entrepreneurship. Students participate in events that test their skills in areas such as finance, marketing, and management. DECA aims to prepare students for future careers by providing real-world business experiences and networking opportunities. The organization supports students' personal and professional growth through competitive events and educational programs. DECA fosters a passion for business and helps students develop leadership and problem-solving skills.

title: Arizona State University
subtitle: Barrett Summer Scholars
raw_text: Barrett Summer Scholars offers high school students an opportunity to explore college life and academic subjects through engaging coursework and hands-on experiences. Students will participate in classes taught by ASU faculty and gain insight into college-level learning while earning college credit.

title: Beaverworks
subtitle: MIT
raw_text: The MIT Beaver Works Summer Institute (BWSI) is a rigorous, world-class STEM program for talented students who will be entering their senior year in high school. The four-week program teaches STEM skills through project-based, workshop-style courses. BWSI began in 2016 with a single course offered to 46 students, a mix of local daytime students and outof-state residential students. In this course, RACECAR (Rapid Autonomous Complex Environment Competing Ackermann steering), students programmed small robotic cars to autonomously navigate a racetrack.

title: Biotechnology Sequencing (BTS) Camp
subtitle: UMich
raw_text: The BTS camp will give you the skills to analyze next-gen raw sequencing data through the use of the Linux operating system and various Linux commands to run programs. This camp is all computational but a crucial component of sequencing research. Sequencing data analysis is a skillset highly sought in many biomedical labs. Like all our camps, this is also a research camp where you will generate results while learning necessary science and skills. Sounds intimidating? No worries. We have wonderful, fun group leaders who will guide you along the way. No programming experience is needed, but we will assume you have a high school biology-level understanding of transcription and translation. Though minimal knowledge is required, we do need your attention, curiosity, and most importantly, open mind to fully engage, including participating in oddball games.

title: Math Modeling Challenge
subtitle: MathWorks
raw_text: The MathWorks Math Modeling Challenge is an online competition where high school students develop mathematical models to solve real-world problems. Participants work in teams to create and present their models. The challenge aims to promote mathematical modeling skills and teamwork. Winners receive recognition and awards for their solutions. The competition supports the development of practical mathematical skills and problem-solving techniques.

title: UC Berkeley
subtitle: UC Berkeley M.E.T. Innovation Academy
raw_text: The UC Berkeley M.E.T. Innovation Academy is designed for students to explore the intersection of technology and business while engaging in hands-on projects that foster creativity and innovation through collaboration with faculty and industry experts.

title: GEnYuS
subtitle: UIUC
raw_text: GEnYuS – This program focuses on physics research. If you are interested in dark matter, lasers, or materials, then the GEnYuS program may be right for you.

title: ISYM Programs
subtitle: UIUC
raw_text: The Illinois Summer Youth Music (ISYM) program offers comprehensive music education and performance opportunities for young musicians. It provides a range of programs, including band, orchestra, choir, and jazz ensembles, designed to enhance students' skills and knowledge in various musical disciplines. Each program focuses on both individual and group instruction, led by experienced faculty and guest artists. Students participate in rehearsals, masterclasses, and performances, tailored to their skill levels and interests. The program aims to foster musical growth, creativity, and collaboration among participants.

title: DREAMBIG Academy
subtitle: UNL
raw_text: You are the future of business. Spend a few days in July at the College of Business to learn about the dynamic world of business and explore potential career opportunities. You’ll make connections with people with similar goals as you as well as interact with faculty and staff who will push you to do your best as you sharpen leadership and networking skills. Walk away with new friends and perspective, resources to tackle the college admissions process and potentially qualify for a renewable $2,000 scholarship for completing the program.

title: STEM Camp
subtitle: SAME
raw_text: Start Your STEM Journey Today! SAME’s STEM/Engineering & Construction Camps offer high school students interested in a highly unique STEM experience the chance to spend a week at a military base learning engineering, construction and design, while developing leadership skills and discovering the potential of a career in STEM. Led by SAME professionals and other volunteers from the military and engineering community, for more than 20 years the SAME Camps Program has focused on practical, project-based learning that provides hands-on opportunities to explore STEM fields and to chart a course for future education and career opportunities. SAME camps feature an impressive record of producing thousands of engineers and STEM leaders. They provide a rigorous experience for students interested in exploring STEM skills and careers. During the week, campers gain a sense of what it takes to become a STEM professional and learn what options exist to explore that interest from high school to college and beyond. Each camp has a unique curriculum that features hands-on activities conducted in competitive environments promoting teamwork, leadership, project management, and problem-solving.

title: Global Youth Program
subtitle: UPENN
raw_text: Wharton generates global perspectives and creates leaders who grow economies, organizations, and opportunities that transcend borders. Wharton offers programs on every continent for students, faculty, alumni, and executives. We are a global community, with an MBA class that is 33% international and an alumni network that extends to the highest levels in every sector in 153 countries.

title: USAFA
subtitle: Cadet Summer Research Program
raw_text: The Cadet Summer Research Program at the U.S. Air Force Academy offers cadets the opportunity to engage in research projects under faculty supervision. Participants gain hands-on experience in various STEM fields while developing their research skills and contributing to ongoing scientific inquiries.

title: China Scholars Program
subtitle: Stanford SPICE
raw_text: The China Scholars Program (CSP) is a synchronous online course for high school students in the United States, sponsored by the Stanford Program on International and Cross-Cultural Education and the Freeman Spogli Institute for International Studies (FSI). Students explore key issues in contemporary China, spanning politics, economics, social issues, culture, and the arts, emphasizing its relationship with the United States. This one-semester, college-level course offers students a rare opportunity to develop expertise on a rising world power of critical importance in every aspect of 21st-century global dynamics.

title: Summer College
subtitle: UChicago
raw_text: Join us online this summer to explore new subjects, delve into a current interest with intense focus, and broaden your powers of perception while taking undergraduate courses at the University of Chicago. As a Summer Session student, you have the opportunity to enroll in undergraduate courses drawn from the regular curriculum of the College at the University of Chicago.

title: NeuroScience Summer Program
subtitle: UW
raw_text: The UW Medicine Department of Neuroscience Summer Student Program provides “Bench to Bedside” exposure in the field of neurosciences. Established in 2008 by Richard G. Ellenbogen, M.D., Professor and Chair of the UW Department of Neurological Surgery, the program provides students seeking summer lab placements the opportunity to explore basic and clinical neurosciences. Our hope is that students will be so excited by their work that they will desire to pursue an academic career in research and/or medicine.

title: CED emBARC Academy
subtitle: UCB
raw_text: Spend your summer immersed in the world of architecture, urban design, and sustainable city planning on the UC Berkeley campus. embARC is an engaging college-level course that offers you the chance to study at the top-ranked public university for architecture and the built environment alongside students from all over the world. Challenging design assignments, one-on-one reviews with instructors, field trips around the Bay Area, and a design/build project for a community nonprofit introduce you to the skills, ideas, and culture of an environmental design education. You'll leave the program with a strong portfolio for your college applications in any area of environmental design and credit on an official UC Berkeley transcript.

title: ESTEEM/SER-Quest Summer Program
subtitle: UMD
raw_text: The ESTEEM Research Mentoring Program (Engineering Science and Technology to Energize and Expand Young Minds) and the Summer Engineering Research (SER)-Quest is an intensive 4-week research-focused program sponsored by the Center for Minorities in Science and Engineering.

title: University of Delaware
subtitle: EDGE Program
raw_text: The EDGE Program at the University of Delaware offers high school students an opportunity to explore college life while earning college credits. Participants engage in hands-on learning experiences and gain insight into various academic disciplines. The program fosters personal growth and academic development in a supportive environment.

title: OU Health
subtitle: High School and Undergraduate Programs
raw_text: This program offers high school and undergraduate students the opportunity to engage in cancer research through hands-on experiences. Participants will work alongside experienced researchers and gain valuable insights into the field of medicine while contributing to ongoing cancer research initiatives.

title: FAA Summer Intensive
subtitle: UIUC
raw_text: At this immersive, weeklong program, each high school student selects a track for the week. Students stay in our state-of-the-art resident halls, and the tracks run 9:00 a.m.–12:00 p.m. and 1:30 p.m.–4:30 p.m. Monday–Friday. Current College of Fine and Applied Arts faculty members, graduate students, and recent alums teach classes. Participants also join in evening activities such as bowling, movies on the Quad, exploring campus, scavenger hunts, and museum trips. All the Art and Design tracks include a special session at Japan House.

title: Neuroscape Research Internship
subtitle: UCSF
raw_text: The Neuroscape Summer High School Internship at UCSF provides students with the opportunity to work in a neuroscience research lab. Interns assist with ongoing research projects, gaining hands-on experience in neuroscience and related fields. The program includes mentorship from researchers, educational workshops, and lab activities. It aims to inspire students to pursue careers in neuroscience and biomedical research. The internship offers valuable exposure to scientific research and professional development in a cutting-edge field.

title: Summer Academy
subtitle: RWU
raw_text: Rising high school Juniors and Seniors get a taste of the college experience, earning three college credits through a variety of studio, seminar, field work and extracurricular activities. Students understand architecture as a possible area of college study, and as a career.

title: Discovery to Cure Program
subtitle: Yale
raw_text: The Discovery to Cure Internship Program was established in 2003 by Dr. Gil Mor, Professor of Obstetrics, Gynecology & Reproductive Sciences, with the goal of exposing students from local schools to Yale's biomedical laboratories to open their minds to pursue career opportunities in science and medicine. The initial program enrolled four students from two local high schools with the participation of two laboratories at the Department of Obstetrics Gynecology and Reproductive Sciences. Since then, the program has grown to include over 41 schools from throughout the country as well as internationally. The program now includes undergraduates and teachers. The program is highly competitive (less than 12% acceptance) and since its inception, a total of over 300 high school students, undergraduates, and high school teachers have successfully completed the Program. Several interns have presented their research work at science fairs, including the Connecticut Junior Science and Humanities Symposium at UCONN, the National JSHS, Pfizer Life Science Award, Connecticut State Science Fair, International Science and Engineering Fair and the Siemens Westinghouse Science and Technology Competition, achieving semifinalist, finalist and first place status. Approximately 20% of the students have published their findings in peer-reviewed scientific journals.

title: Sports Journalism Summer Camp
subtitle: UMD
raw_text: The Shirley Povich Sports Journalism Summer Camp has become one of the most popular camps for high school students interested in sports media. Students are taught by professionals in the field and gain valuable hands-on, real-world experiences. Held annually in July, the summer camp is for high school students entering grades 9-12 and attracts students from all across the country. The 2024 summer camp will be held July 8-12 from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. at Knight Hall on the University of Maryland campus. Our camp is full and registration is now closed.

title: Science Academy
subtitle: UCSD
raw_text: The Sally Ride Science Academy summer program offers science, technology, engineering, arts and math (STEAM) workshops for students entering 3rd-12th grade. During these workshops, students assume the roles of space explorer, marine biologist, computer programmer and more as they immerse themselves in hands-on projects. Top-notch STEAM instructors lead these workshops, serving as both teachers and role models. These summer workshops also incorporate real-life stories of vibrant women conducting research in each field. Their examples inspire students and help make STEAM careers more accessible.

title: Double Discovery Center

The success of our mission relies heavily on the generosity of our donors, whose contributions are vital in making a lasting impact in these communities.

title: Scholars Program
subtitle: QuestBridge
raw_text: Top colleges and universities are looking for students who have excelled academically despite financial hardship, and they partner with QuestBridge to find students like you. title: NM GCM Grosvenor Program

The program focuses on developing essential skills and offering insights into the healthcare field, preparing students for future career opportunities. It also emphasizes personal and professional growth through mentoring and career exploration activities. Overall, the NM Discovery Program aims to inspire and inform students about potential career paths in healthcare.

title: Annual Challenge

enhanced_description: The Young Scientist Lab Annual Challenge provides high school students with a professional platform to develop and present innovative scientific projects that address significant questions or problems. This competition aims to foster a deep interest in scientific research and problem-solving by allowing participants to showcase their unique talents and creativity. title: Terrapin Music Camp

title: Finance Camp
subtitle: PSU
raw_text: This camp will prepare today’s teenagers for the financial twists and turns of growing up in the 21st century. This program will focus on the mathematics that adults are faced with on a daily, weekly, or monthly basis. Campers will be introduced to career planning, personal budgeting, basic banking, how credit works, school loans, auto payments & auto insurance.

title: Host-Microbe Mutualism
subtitle: UMass
raw_text: Our competitive Research Intensives program places high-achieving high school students in professional working labs alongside distinguished faculty, graduate and undergraduate students. Research Intensive in the Host-Microbe Symbiosis Lab (Wang Lab) Plants and animals frequently engage microbes in mutualistic interactions, some of which have significant impacts on our society and the ecosystem. Because such interactions are complex by nature, we are using one well-studied system as an example to probe the molecular mechanisms needed to establish symbiotic relationships in general. Legumes (beans, peas, etc.) play hosts to a class of bacteria that can convert nitrogen in the atmosphere into plant food. This nitrogen-fixing symbiosis is of great importance to sustainable development, and also has medical implications for human health.

title: UTEP
subtitle: Summer Research Academy
raw_text: The Summer Research Academy at UTEP offers high school students the opportunity to engage in hands-on research experiences in engineering. Participants will work closely with faculty mentors and gain valuable skills in a supportive academic environment. This program aims to inspire future engineers and scientists.

title: Summer Session
subtitle: UChicago
raw_text: In addition to over 1,000 current undergraduate and graduate students, Summer Session at the University of Chicago will welcome nearly 1,000 academically talented high school students from around the world to participate in virtual intensive study within UChicago's unique scholarly environment. The Summer Session Office in the College hires faculty, senior lecturers, lecturers, and graduate students to teach summer quarter undergraduate courses in a variety of subjects, as well as specially designed courses for pre-college (academically advanced high school students ready to study at the undergraduate level) and visiting undergraduate students.

title: Discover Actuarial Science
subtitle: UNL
raw_text: Are you a current high school sophomore or junior who enjoys math, solving problems and helping people make good decisions? title: Underwater Robotics Competition
subtitle: Mate Rov

title: Summer Academics
subtitle: UPENN
raw_text: Academies are subject-intensive three-week programs that fuse sophisticated scientific or social theory with relevant applications. Academies are led by University of Pennsylvania faculty and long-standing professionals in their field of study with support from graduate and undergraduate teaching assistants.

title: University of Maine

raw_text: This program allows students to engage in self-directed research projects under the guidance of faculty mentors. title: Discover How the Systems of the Body Work Together
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: Anatomy and physiology work together to define how the human body operates by explaining the function and structure of its many components. This course provides you with a comprehensive view of the major body regions and systems through engaging course videos featuring a variety of educational tools and procedures including cadaver dissection. Explore the musculoskeletal, nervous, cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, and gastrointestinal systems, and apply your knowledge to scenarios from a variety of related fields.

title: Marketing & Personal Branding Academy
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: In this program, students will learn the fundamentals of the field of marketing through an intercultural lens, at both the business and personal levels. By the end of the program, students will create and pitch their own marketing campaigns and learn to better pitch their unique skills and aspirations.

title: Summer Learning Academy

Participants work on team projects, explore various STEM topics, and interact with professionals and mentors in the industry. The virtual format allows students to participate from anywhere, making the camp accessible to a wider audience. Overall, the SLA Virtual Camp aims to inspire and prepare students for future STEM careers by providing a comprehensive and engaging educational experience.

raw_text: This program offers high school students a chance to gain hands-on experience in botanic gardens. Interns will work on various projects related to horticulture education and conservation. title: Coding for Game Design
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: Have you ever wanted to create your own video game? Through this two-week program, students learn about the principles of game design, and are introduced to C# and Unity scripting, which they use to create their own custom games! The program emphasizes team collaboration and close work with experienced game designers and developers from NYU Steinhardt’s Consortium for Research and Evaluation of Advanced Technologies in Education (CREATE). Students will work together and independently to create 3D Unity games based on design principles and development techniques used by professionals at NYU.

title: Plant The Moon Challenge

title: Quantum Quickstart
subtitle: UChicago
raw_text: Quantum mechanics has reshaped how we see the world around us, being hailed as a science with the potential to fundamentally redefine the technological landscape and our society. Information encoded in quantum bits is known to be completely secure from hacking; computers running on quantum algorithms can solve problems that no classical computer could ever solve; and quantum systems enable the world’s most precise measurements.

title: Summer Camp
subtitle: GRAMMY
raw_text: GRAMMY Camp is a 7-day non-residential music industry program for high school students interested in careers in music that takes place every July in Los Angeles. GRAMMY Camp faculty of music professionals, as well as guest professionals, provide valuable insight to give campers the best chance at achieving success in their chosen career.

title: Dartmouth College

title: Summer Session
subtitle: UCI
raw_text: The UCI Summer Session offers a variety of educational programs, including undergraduate and graduate courses, for students seeking to advance their studies or explore new interests. The program aims to provide flexibility and accessibility, allowing students to earn credits, gain new skills, and prepare for future academic or professional goals. Additionally, it includes opportunities for personal enrichment and professional development through specialized courses and workshops. Overall, UCI's Summer Session is designed to enhance learning and provide valuable experiences in a dynamic academic environment.

title: Bridges to Social Justice Academy
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: This 2-Week Academy serves as an introduction to the multiple pathways that you can take toward the creation of a more just and humane world. Grounded in both the Social Change Model of Leadership (SCML) and the Pathways of Public Service and Civic Engagement framework, this academy will provide you with content and context to support your understanding of the injustices and structural oppression perpetuating harm in our society. We will focus on the HOW: the intersecting and necessary ways to create social change through community-engaged research; community organizing and activism; direct service; decolonial philanthropy; advocacy for public policy; and social entrepreneurship for the common good. Through this exploration, you will develop a self-awareness of your own strengths and capacities for participation in work for social change. These two weeks will also provide you the opportunity to explore how your future college studies and careers can contribute to combating injustice and building peace.

title: ICS Summer Academy
subtitle: UCI
raw_text: We invite talented high school students to participate in our ICS Summer Academy, which will be held this summer in person on our beautiful UCI campus. After the successful inaugural offerings of the Academy in Summer 2022 and 2023, we are pleased to announce that, based on feedback from parents, guardians, and students, we have added two new courses for Summer 2024. Students can apply for admission and register for up to two of four offerings: Data Analytics; Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning; Cryptography & Security; and Software Engineering.

title: FPE Summer Camp
subtitle: UMD
raw_text: The Fire Protection Engineering Design Challenge (FPEDC) camp is a week-long design and construction camp that ends in a team competition. In teams of 3 or 4, participants will design, test and build a two-room apartment along with the notification, detection and suppression systems in that apartment. The teams will bring their apartments to be fire-tested in a competition at the end of the week in the University of Maryland fire labs. The summer camp is housed at 4403 Frederick Avenue, Baltimore, MD 21229, at Mount St. Joseph's Catholic High School.  Though the camp is offered at an all-boys school, this summer program is open to all who are interested to attend!  The SFPE (Society of Fire Protection Engineers) Chesapeake Chapter and Mount St. Joseph's school will collaborate to provide the teaching for the camp.  The final 'Burn Day' competition will be staffed by current FPE students, staff and faculty.

title: OSU

title: UMass

subtitle: Roswell Park
raw_text: The Roswell Park High School Summer Research Program offers high school juniors in Western New York hands-on research experience in cancer science. title: Summer Scholars Research Program
subtitle: Emory
raw_text: The Summer Scholars Research Program at Winship Cancer Institute of Emory University is a six-week internship focused on exposing students to cancer research. en to twelve students will work one-on-one with a Winship physician or lab-based researcher, conduct research in a working lab or clinic setting, attend field trips to places like the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention David J. Sencer Museum and the Georgia Institute of Technology, and hear lectures from a variety of specialists in oncology-related careers. Through this exposure and education, we hope to encourage students to pursue cancer research.

title: Investigation and Training in Careers in Health

title: Future Leaders Program
subtitle: UCI
raw_text: The Merage School Future Leaders Initiative (FLI) guides, inspires, and empowers high school and community college students from Southern California’s underserved communities. A community outreach and certificate program consisting of remote and in person courses, FLI focuses on delivering a tailored business education, providing access to financial literacy courses, with the goal of encouraging university enrollment, increasing college readiness and preparing students for careers at the intersection of business, technology and entrepreneurship. The Future Leaders Initiative leverages UCI’s state-of-the-art educational resources, the expertise of globally renowned faculty and leading-edge curricula to offer hands-on mentorship and professional training in these crucial academic areas.

title: Pre-College

raw_text: The Summer Pre-College Programs at Susquehanna showcase the university’s colleges of the arts, business, humanities and sciences by offering exciting and engaging, weeklong on-campus workshops designed especially for high-achieving high school students. title: SYCCL
subtitle: Stony Brook
raw_text: The Institute for Advanced Computational Science and Department of Linguistics at Stony Brook University is offering a 10-day camp introducing middle and high school students to computational linguistics and language technology.  This camp will be held remotely, with both synchronous and asynchronous components.  There is no age requirement for this camp.  If enough children of different ages apply, we may run different classes for different age groups.  No prior knowledge of programming or formal linguistics is assumed. This hands-on camp introduces students to both the wonder of natural languages and the analytical methods that underlay the natural language technology people use every day in all parts of the world.

title: Stevens Institute of Technology
subtitle: Stevens Technical Enrichment Program
raw_text: The Art Harper Saturday Academy is a free program designed for middle and high school students to explore STEM fields through hands-on activities and workshops. title: Discover the Fast-Paced World of Journalism
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: Throughout history, the world has relied on journalists to keep us informed about current events and issues. In today’s digital world, the field of journalism has and will continue to evolve and expand—careers like multimedia editor, social media specialist, podcaster, content writer, and more have become increasingly necessary to keep the world in the know. This course introduces you to the foundations of this ever-changing world, including how to craft a story, interview subjects, and identify pitfalls within the industry. Various experts such as news correspondents, prize winning journalists, reporters, and political editors from renowned news and media outlets discuss why they chose this field and how they specialized their skill set.

title: CEAT - Automation and Robotics Discovery
subtitle: Oklahoma State
raw_text: Students in 9th through 12th grades can take advantage of a great opportunity to introduce themselves to the basics of electrical engineering, industrial automation, and mechatronics systems.  This unique summer camp is perfect for anyone considering a career in engineering and engineering technology, as it combines college level introductory courses with hands-on activities.  Starts Monday at 1pm & ends Friday at 1pm, 8am - 5pm each day with evening functions and activities.  Attendance is $499 per person. Registration includes all accommodations, meals, supplies, and a shirt. Seats are limited so be sure to register soon

title: Kimberly Querrey Research
subtitle: Northwestern
raw_text: Each selected intern is thoughtfully matched with a Northwestern faculty member and given a hypothesis-driven or hypothesis-generating basic or clinical research project. Each intern’s project will make a meaningful contribution to their laboratory’s research and help advance our understanding of the mechanisms that drive lung disease. The research training is coupled with activities that prepare interns for the college/graduate school application process, success in college/graduate school, and development of their professional careers in science and/or medicine. The research experience culminates with a presentation at the annual Kimberly Querrey Summer Research Symposium.

title: William & Mary
subtitle: WM TIP
raw_text: The William & Mary Talent Identification Program offers academically talented middle and high school students the opportunity to explore their interests in various subjects through engaging courses and activities designed to challenge and inspire them. Students will develop critical thinking skills and foster a love for learning in a supportive environment.

title: Innovation in Music Academy
subtitle: UCLA
raw_text: This program will give students a foundational overview of how the music business has been transformed by decades of technological and business innovation. Innovation led to music sampling and musical effects in hip-hop. The rise of music videos created a global, multicultural market for recorded music. Digitization created a renaissance for the industry and would later disrupt it entirely – first with Napster and then with iTunes. Today, streaming services like Spotify, Internet-connected devices, digital and mobile ticketing, and stadium technologies are radically changing the ways audiences consume and pay for music and music based experiences. This ongoing evolution continues to shape the business – impacting labels, artists, live event promoters and others pursuing careers in music. And future successful careers will depend on understanding business models, management principles, and techniques for working and leading in an innovative music industry.

title: Pre-College
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: This summer, join us for an exciting learning program at Georgetown University. Our Hoya Summer High School Sessions offer the opportunity to explore your academic interests, meet classmates from around the world, and earn college credit—all while experiencing the excitement of college life.

title: Johns Hopkins University
subtitle: WISE Program
raw_text: The WISE Program at Johns Hopkins University offers high school girls the opportunity to explore engineering through hands-on activities and mentorship. subtitle: UTA

title: Brown University

raw_text: This program offers students a unique opportunity to explore Oxford's rich academic environment while engaging in experiential learning. title: UCI

raw_text: The Summer Youth Science Fellowship Program at UCI offers high school students the opportunity to engage in cancer research through hands-on experience.
